|                  |the Allotment amount available. The report should capture the following data elements:                            |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |Columns-                                                                                                          |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• BEP Fiscal Year                                                                                                 |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• BEP Appropriation Code                                                                                          |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• Allotment Code                                                                                                  |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• BEP Amount Available                                                                                            |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• Allotment Amount Available                                                                                      |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• Difference                                                                                                      |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |Rows-                                                                                                             |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• Each unique combination of BEP Appropriation Code and Allotment Code                                            |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |

|                  |xx/xx/xxxx. This report shows a preliminary view of the year end BEP codes. The report should capture the         |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |following data elements:                                                                                          |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• Budget Execution Plan                                                                                           |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |

|                  |• Name                                                                                                            |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |

|                  |This report reflects reimbursable expenditures billed in financial system for collection of IPACs.  The dates are |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |chosen via the financial system GUI and this report can be run at any time. The report should capture the         |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |

|                  |Headers-                                                                                                          |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• Trading Partner Code                                                                                            |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• Trading Partner Institution                                                                                     |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• Program Element                                                                                                 |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |Columns-                                                                                                          |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• Appropriation                                                                                                   |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• Obligation ID                                                                                                   |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• ALC Code                                                                                                        |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• Trading Partner Reference Number                                                                                |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• 1080                                                                                                            |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• Total Amount                                                                                                    |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• Post Amount                                                                                                     |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |Rows-                                                                                                             |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |• Each entry for the Trading Partner Reference Number                                                             |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |

|RP-06: MS Access Transitioned Reports                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |
|RP-06-01          |The system must have the capability to generate a  Daily Batch report that provides a listing of all payments that|MS Access                |M                     |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |will be in the next day's treasury submission by input user. This report is used to reconcile the treasury        |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |submission.                                                                                                       |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|RP-06-02          |The system must have the capability to generate an open 914's report that provides a listing of all cancelled     |MS Access                |M                     |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |payments and the last date banking was updated. This report is used to determine when cancelled payments can be   |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |reissued.                                                                                                         |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |

|                  |interest payments that were made using reimbursable funds. This report is used to move interest expenditures to   |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |non-reimbursable dollars.                                                                                         |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|RP-06-04          |The system must have the capability to generate a  SF 1174 Interim Vouchers report that provides a listing of     |MS Access                |M                     |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |pre-paid TDY expensed paid through the 1164 process. This is used to ensure the dollars reimbursed on the 1164 are|                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |not also claimed on the travel expense report.                                                                    |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|RP-06-05          |The system must have the capability to generate a  sortable list of panelists names that allows a user to         |MS Access                |M                     |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |search/query a database of panelists and panel IDs. This is used to post ticket charges.                          |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|RP-06-06          |The system must have the capability to generate a  tax information/1099 report that provides a list of all        |MS Access                |M                     |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |payments made to a particular social security number.                                                             |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|RP-06-07          |The system must have the capability to generate an expiring appropriations report that provides a list of all     |MS Access                |M                     |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |obligations funded with the current dying appropriation that have outstanding invoices. This is provides to DACS  |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |branch and is used by DFM to clear all invoices before year end.                                                  |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|RP-06-10          |The system must have the capability to generate a  FUBS with unliquidated balances in hold report. This report    |MS Access                |M                     |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |lists all grants placed in FUB hold queue at the start of the quarter that currently have positive unliquidated   |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |balances.                                                                                                         |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|RP-06-11          |The system must have the capability to generate a  FUBS of concern report after the FUBS in hold report is run in |MS Access                |M                     |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |order to obtain current data. This query will produce a report that shows only grants with unliquidated balances  |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |of $7,000 or more or balances 40% greater than grant amount zero.                                                 |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |

|                  |                                                                                                                  |                         |Value-Added           |the Box? (Yes or No)              |                                                      |
|CA-01: Cost Allocation                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          |
|CA-01-01          | The system must have the capability to calculate and apply the cost allocation method for all transactions       |NSF Requirement          |M                     |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |interfaced from the Payment Processing System, based on the order of the following criteria:                      |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |1- Period of Performance of Award                                                                                 |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |2- Appropriation Year (the year the funds were appropriated)                                                      |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |3- Funds cancelling first (appropriation cancellation date)                                                       |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |4- External Funds or Other Special Appropriations (eg, other Agency funds or ARRA)                                |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |5- Allocate based on amounts of amendments / splits (prorated based on the percentage of funds obligated)         |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |
|CA-01-02          |The system must have the capability to remove ("turn off") criterion number 4 (external funds or other special    |NSF Requirement          |M                     |                                  |                                                      |
|                  |appropriations) from the cost allocation method on a case-by-case, as needed basis.                               |                         |                      |                                  |                                                      |

2

1 Background
The Financial Accounting System (FAS) is NSFs primary vehicle for managing funding. Central transaction management represents the core of the system, handling transaction processing, accounts maintenance, transaction history, and rules processing. The system includes reporting capabilities to assist NSF in verifying funds throughout the fiscal year. The system supports extensive editing for transactions input through the FAS as well as through other systems that interface with FAS. The iTRAK solution will replace FAS and should be a fully integrated financial management system. It shall use commercial off the shelf (COTS) products to leverage financial management system best practices.

2 FAS Interfaces
FAS is integrated with several grants management as well as administrative systems at NSF mainly for posting financial and non financial transactions; and utilizing FAS data as reference data for look ups, validations, and reporting. The following Table 1: FAS Interfaces provides a summary of the systems interfacing with FAS.
Table 1: FAS Interfaces

Name Awards

Interaction Financial and Non-financial transactions

Description Provides the Division of Grants and Agreements (DGA) with the tools to process all award actions electronically to include approving, reviewing, and logging award actions. In addition, it allows DGA to compose an award letter and upon approval, send an electronic notification to the grantee. eJacket is an end-to-end web-based grants management system that allows NSF staff to view and process proposals electronically from receipt in the external facing grants applications systems through post-award management. Fellowship applicants, reference writers, fellows, and university officials can manage fellowship activities and exchange information online The Guest Travel system is a web-based application for travel obligations and payment requests for non-NSF employees, specifically panelists. Currently a custom built interface with a legacy training system for internal and external training needs. It will be 3

eJacket

Financial and Non-financial transactions

GRFP (Graduate Financial and Research Non-financial Fellowship Program transactions system) Guest Travel Financial and Non-financial transactions Financial and Non-financial

Training System (at

Name NSF)

Interaction transactions

Description replaced by an eLearning system.
Note: This interface can be retired if the new solution has a built-in interface with the e-Learning service provider

Institution System

Non-financial transactions

Institution system is a custom built application for maintaining vendors and grantees data and is used for the NSF Grants Management Systems. Grant systems require specific information for reporting, audit and compliance. In the future state, new grantee and vendor header records are updated in Institution and sent to the financial system. A future interface, as a replacement and enhancement of Federal Financial Reporting functionality in FastLane and Research.gov systems, to be implemented before the iTRAK implementation. It will allow grantees to request payments at the individual grant level in near/real time. Expected frequencies of payment transactions are between 2,000 and 25,000 daily, with an average expected frequency of 11,000 daily. A future interface that will store current and historic financial data providing end user reporting for financial and operational information across the enterprise. Interfaces with the FedTraveler system hosted by HP with FAS. \
Note: This interface can be retired if the new solution has a built-in interface with the e-Travel service provider

Payment Processing Financial and Non-financial transactions

Data Warehouse

Data Extract and Load

eTravel interface (at Financial and NSF) Non-financial transactions

CCR batch program (at NSF)

Non-financial transactions

Currently, CCR data is used for vendor payments, but not grantee payments. In the future state, the institution application will provide the header information to include name and DUNS +4, and CCR will provide detailed information including address and banking information for both vendors and grantees. FPPS is the NSF component of the DOI Federal Personnel Payroll System hosted at National Business Center (NBC). FPPS links payroll cost and personnel information from DOI/NBCs FPPS with NSFs Financial Accounting System (FAS) and Integrated Time and Attendance System (ITAS).

FPPS (Federal Personnel Payroll System) Interface program (at NSF)

Financial and Non-financial transactions

4

Name Bank Information Validation Service Purchase Card

Interaction Non-financial transactions Financial and Non-financial transactions

Description Updates bank information in FAS. Procurement card transactions downloaded from the procurement card provider and uploaded into the financial system for payment and reporting.

Refer to Appendix A for additional information on the systems interfacing with FAS

3 iTRAK Interface Requirements
NSF is in the process of changing the FAS interfaces to operate on "Open Standards" such as Web Services and Data Services. This transition is planned to be completed in time for the iTRAK implementation. With this being the assumption the iTRAK system integrator is expected to integrate the COTS system with NSFs legacy systems as listed in section 2.0 using a standards based open architecture APIs as listed below. 3.1

Proposed Integration Architecture:

For transactional interfaces NSF plans on Web Services architecture using SOAP, HTTPs, WSDL, XML and JMS. The security on the interface must be FIPS complaint. The solution should support both synchronous (real-time) and a-synchronous (near real-time) transactions as well as processing transactions in batch. For the data integration platform NSF plans on using data services that would periodically push the data from iTRAK to the NSFs Enterprise Data Warehouse. NSFs Enterprise Data Warehouse is hosted on Oracle 10g database platform as outlined in Figure 1: iTRAK Integration Landscape. 3.2 Interfacing with Business Services Layer: NSF will work with the iTRAK integrator to establish the contract that includes the schema definitions and WSDL signatures for processing a business transaction. A list of sample input and output parameters are identified in Appendix B. The integrator is expected to plug-in the respective COTS based APIs with in the business layer built by NSF as outlined in Figure 1: iTRAK Integration Landscape. Figure 1: iTRAK Integration Landscape

5

3.3

List of Business Transactions

The following Table 2: Business Transactions provides a list of business transactions consumed by the interfaced applications.
Table 2: Business Transactions

Service Name Post Financial Transaction

Get Bill ID Get Disbursement ID Insert Disbursement Record Insert Travel Information 3.4

Description Post a financial transaction such as a commitment, obligation, payment, journal entry; as well as perform a funds check against the accounting system Get a new Bill ID for processing receivables Get a new Disbursement ID for processing payments Insert Disbursement information for processing payments Insert information related to a travel obligation

Data Extraction

As identified in Figure:1 iTRAK Integration Landscape, the iTRAK solution should have capability to extract data such as reference data and transactional data, from the Core Financial system and load it into NSF staging area for it to be available for other systems and reporting/analytics. The iTRAK system integrator would be responsible for extracting the data from the new system and loading it to the staging area as specified. The frequency of data load would be on a daily basis.

6

The new solution should have a capability to extract data into the Data Warehouse. NSF would work with the iTRAK system integrator to identify data objects to be loaded in the staging area. A list of sample reference data objects is mentioned below: Appropriation Organization Program Object Class Code Individual data Grantee and Vendor data Custom Reference Codes (to be identified during implementation) 3.5

Integration with NSF's Enterprise Identity Management System

For the Identity integration NSF plans on using identity services to consume Authentication information to log into the application. iTRAK should have the capability to consume SAML (Secured Assertion Markup Language) OR Web Services for user authentication to the system. 3.6

COTS Integration Capability

As identified under the COTS integration block in Figure: 1 iTRAK Integration Landscape, it is desired that the offered solution includes built-in interfaces with standard Federal interfaces that are used at NSF. A list of the standard Federal interfaces are identified in Table 3: Standard Federal Interfaces below. Currently these products are integrated using custom interfaces and NSF plans to retire them once the new iTRAK solution is implemented.
Table 3: Standard Federal Interfaces

Name Central Contractor Registry (CCR) Treasury

Description Integration with CCR.gov Integration with Treasury to provide the following data extracts: FACTS I FACTS II SF-224 GFRS Statements SF-133 Intragovernmental Transaction Support List Disbursement Support Listing IFCS IRAS GTAS (January 2013) 7

IPAC GOALS II/IAS RFC Agency Link SPS PAM IPP GWA FPPS eTravel System Purchase Card eLearning system Interface with DOIs FPPS system Interface with the eTravel system Interface to import travel and purchase card transactions Interface with an eLearning system for processing training requests for external training, modifications, and internal transfers. Updates bank information in the financial system.

Bank Information Validation Service

4 System Requirements
Each business transaction should be processed in iTRAK and sent back to the NSF systems with 2 seconds on a near real-time scenario. In a near real-time scenario, upon failure to communicate the response to NSF systems, the system should make 5 consecutive tries within a duration of 60 seconds before throwing any exceptions. iTRAK should provide proper reconciliation reports for all business transaction through the interface. The interfaces should be available 24x7x365 except on planned outages. The interfaces should be able to support 50 concurrent transactions without performance degradation. Any planned outages should be notified to NSF at least 6 weeks in advance. All changes to the interfaces endpoints should be documented and communicated to NSF at least 8 weeks in advance. All production incidents should be responded with 2 hours. The incidents should be documented and communicated to NSF via proper communication channels and escalated to the IT Help Center. The data load from iTRAK to NSF staging area should happen on a daily basis (every 24 hours) or near/real time or on demand basis, Supporting documentation (data dictionary, data model) on the data should be provided to NSF. The data transport mechanism should be secured per FIPS 140-2.

8

FPPS Interface

File Formats - FTP Files that are provided: Labor Cost File (COSTFILE), Combined Data File (COMBFILE), Banking Info File (IFIL0131 ­ Incremental & IFIL0079 ­ Full), IPA Extract File (IPAEXT) Transmission : The data files are FTPd from DOI using a UNIX shell script The data files are parsed by FPPS application programs and stored in FPPSDB. Employee Biweekly and daily banking information is consolidated and updated through an interface. Flow of logic for Normalized loading: ˇ ControlM invokes a script that calls an executable java class that runs the Bank Info Normalized Loading interface. ˇ Retrieves all the records whose process status code is ,,01 from Labor Cost Staging table based on the batch Id. ˇ Validates the data and convert to the appropriate data type picking the data type from an xml file. ˇ Retrieves the existing record of the employees Bank Info with the SSN from Bank Info Normalized table. 11

ˇ ˇ ˇ ˇ

Compares the existing record with the new record. If there is no change in the profile, the system ignores the record. If any change, the record is made expired and inserted with the new account particulars. Job start time, Job end time, Job result written to the Job process log table Error logs written to the Record error log table.

All the data files are parsed by FPPS application programs and stored in FPPSDB. Labor Cost data would be consolidated, and merged with NSF translations rules to form accounting transactions and would be posted into FAS system. Payroll accruals are posted manually using payroll transaction codes (TC 652, 654) by appropriation, program element and object class. The accrual is based on the pay period that will post immediately before the end of the quarter. At year end, additional amounts are accrued for terminal leave, intermittent consultants and overtime, as well as Presidential Rank awards (if signed by the President on or before 09/30).

i

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION

DIS SDLC Guide

1. Overview
The SDLC defined here is the system development methodology of the National Science Foundation (NSF) Division of Information Systems (DIS). It is based on a waterfall engineering process that describes who does what, when, and how in a system development and deployment project. It defines the SDLC in terms of phases, deliverables and artifacts. The SDLC is based on guidance from the NSF DIS Deputy Division Director and Branch Chiefs. The purpose of an SDLC methodology is to provide IT Project Managers with the tools to help ensure successful implementation of systems that satisfy NSF strategic and business objectives. The documentation provides a mechanism to ensure that executive leadership, functional managers and users sign-off on the requirements and implementation of the system. The process provides NSF managers and the Project Manager with the visibility of design, development, and implementation status needed to ensure delivery on time and within budget. 1.1 Introduction to This Guide This guide intends to help you understand the NSF DIS SDLC Process to follow when initiating and deploying systems/software at the NSF. This guide contains an overview of the SDLC process, high level activities and deliverables in each lifecycle phase, and instructions for how to tailor the SDLC process to fit your project's needs. After reading this guide, you will be able to:    Understand NSF DIS' SDLC process, Tailor the SDLC process to fit your project's needs, Find and download SDLC templates and procedures.

1.2 Background The National Science Foundation spends millions of dollars each year on the acquisition, design, development, implementation, and maintenance of systems vital to mission programs and administrative functions. The need to plan for and develop safe, secure, and reliable system solutions is heightened by an increasing dependence on technology to provide services, develop products, administer programs, and perform management functions. There is also a need to ensure privacy and security when developing information systems, to establish uniform privacy and protection practices, and to develop acceptable implementation strategies for these practices. The SDLC methodology is designed to satisfy these needs by establishing procedures, and practices governing the initiation, requirements, design, development, testing, deployment, operation, maintenance, enhancement, and eventual retirement of automated information systems. This SDLC methodology shall be used for all Major Development Projects which have been defined as meeting one or more of the following criteria: (1) The estimated total cost of full lifecycle activities equals or exceeds $500K; (2) The project is undertaken to support a critical business function associated with the grants management lifecycle or legislative mandates; or (3) The DIS Deputy Division Director determines that the project requires the special attention and consideration given to a major information technology development project. For upgrades or enhancements not designated as Major Development Projects, project teams are strongly encouraged to tailor and use the planning, requirements analysis, design, development, and testing documentation tools provided by the SDLC to support sound project management practices. 1.3 SDLC Phases The NSF SDLC describes important elements of software development in a common and consistent way. This process is broken down into seven phases. The NSF DIS SDLC provides a standard approach that results in the production of well documented, quality software.

Page 1

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION Figure gure 1: NSF DIS SDLC Phases & Key Deliverables

DIS SDLC Guide

1.3.1 Tailoring the SDLC The concept of roadmaps was introduced to help projects tailor the SDLC to meet their requirements. The type of roadmap adopted will depend on the type of change being implemented. Major Enhancements, Enhancements for example, will require more assets and more planning for risk mitigation than a release made up of defects only. The DIS SDLC has defined five roadmaps for projects to select fr from om during the development life cycle. c The five roadmaps are: 1. New Development 2. Major Enhancements 3. Enhancements and Defects 4. Defects 5. Emergency The roadmaps listed above are to be used with the Roadmap Matrix. This matrix shows which assets should be created or updated for each phase se of the SDLC. The Roadmap Matrix also shows whom is responsible for creating/updating the assets, the review type that should be conducted for the asset, organizations that may participate in some of the reviews (QA, TaSS and NSF Release Engineers) and i if f a procedure or Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) exists to provide guidance in developing the required asset for the selected Roadmap. A roadmap may be tailored to meet the needs of a project. If a required artifact is not needed for a particular
Page 2

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION

DIS SDLC Guide

project, justification must be provided in the Project Charter or Release Summary Document (RSD). The justification for not creating or updating an asset must be provided in the beginning of the project or after the project starts. If in the middle of the development life cycle a project determines that it will not be able to develop a required artifact for the roadmap selected, the Project Charter or RSD must be updated to reflect this change and approved. A more detailed description of the roadmaps can be found in the following sections. 1.3.1.1 New Development A New Development project is defined as being a brand new project that has never released its code to production. The purpose of a new development project is to create/deliver a new Information Technology (IT) solution to the production environment, for the first time, to meet a business need or solve a business problem. An example of a New Development project is launching a system for the first time. 1.3.1.2 Major Enhancements The Major Enhancements roadmap typically consists of enhancement Change Requests (CRs) only and it is for Operations and Maintenance (O&M) projects. The Enhancements roadmap is for projects that already have code in production. An Enhancement may be implemented to modernize, enhance or maintain an existing application. Major Enhancements may also include adding new modules to an existing application. An example of a Major Enhancement is the enhancement of the eJacket application to provide program staff with the ability to process a proposal from end-to-end in one application and in a paperless process (eJacket DD Concur). 1.3.1.3 Enhancements and Defects The Enhancements and Defects roadmap is geared towards releases consisting of CRs that are minor enhancements and defect fixes. This roadmap differs from the Enhancements only roadmap because it also includes defects and the enhancements are on a smaller scale. Major Enhancements should not follow this roadmap. Examples of minor enhancements include improvements to the user interface, adding security related features to online applications, adding functionality to calculate stipends, etc. 1.3.1.4 Defects The Defects roadmap is made up of defects only. A defect is defined as anything that adversely impacts the expected functionality of an application to the user, differs from the requirements, does not function as designed, or otherwise reduces the quality of an application that is in production. Defects fall under Corrective Maintenance which means the repair of identified faults or defects due to design, logic, or coding errors. 1.3.1.5 Emergencies The objective of the Emergencies roadmap is to address critical outages or loss of major functionality in an application within a short timeframe. This loss of major functionality in an application is caused by a defect and the highest priority becomes restoring the application to a fully operational state in as short of time possible. Any new functionality is not considered an emergency; therefore, all emergency requests are defects and not enhancements. An expedited CR process is used to address emergency defects. A request to fix an emergency must be approved. The fix to address the defect will be put into production as soon as it is properly tested. An update of the assets related to fixing the defect is performed after the fix has been implemented in the production environment. Approved emergency change requests allow a production deployment before all the supporting documentation is completed in order to minimize downtime and reduce impacts to application users. For example, the business analyst may update the requirements documentation after the production release. 1.3.2 Certification & Accreditation Criteria OMB A-130 defines a major application as an application that requires special attention to security due to the risk and magnitude of harm resulting from the loss, misuse, or unauthorized access to or modification of the information in the application. NSF categorizes its major applications as Low and Moderate. Currently, NSF does not have High Impact applications in its system inventory. This categorization is defined in FIPS-199, Standards for Security Categorization of Federal Information and Information Systems.
Page 3

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION

DIS SDLC Guide

The following criteria are used as guidance to determine if an application is a major application subject to management review:    The application performs financial transactions. The application functions in direct support of the NSF mission. The impact of the loss of system information to the NSF would be: - Moderate if the application's confidentiality, availability and integrity were compromised. Moderate Impact means the data's unauthorized disclosure would have a serious adverse effect on the NSF's reputation or interest. A serious adverse effect means that, for example, the loss of confidentiality, integrity, or availability might: (i) cause a significant degradation in mission capability; (ii) result in significant damage to organizational assets; (iii) result in significant financial loss; or (iv) result in significant harm to individuals that does not involve loss of life or serious life threatening injuries. - Low if the application data's confidentiality, availability and integrity were compromised. In this situation, a Low Impact means the loss of the data's confidentiality, integrity, or availability could be expected to have a limited adverse effect on NSF. A limited adverse effect means (i) a degradation in mission capability; (ii) result in minor damage to organizational assets; (iii) result in minor financial loss; or (iv) result in minor harm to individuals. The application could continue to operate at a remote location should the application's processing environment at NSF become inoperable. NSF major applications are part of the NSF annual Service Recovery testing.



NIST Special Publication 800-37 defines a minor application as an application, other than a major application, that requires attention to security due to the risk and magnitude of harm resulting from the loss, misuse, or unauthorized access to or modification of the information in the application. NSF's minor applications inherit the security controls and protection measures of the NSF Network and Central Computer Facility (CCF). The NSF Network and CCF is certified and accredited every three years using NIST SP 800-53, Recommended Security Controls for Federal Information Systems and Organizations, security controls. NSF reviews the applications technical security controls during the years a C&A is not required.

Page 4

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION

DIS SDLC Guide

2. Reviews
2.1 Artifact Reviews Each artifact should go through a review process prior to being approved. Reviews include project team peer reviews, quality assurance reviews, and reviews with various NSF stakeholders. Peer reviews are an important part of the SDLC process and can save a significant amount of effort and cost when deficiencies are caught early in the lifecycle when they are the least expensive to fix. Appendix A lists the reviews required for each artifact by lifecycle phase prior to the management gate reviews. 2.2 Management Gate Reviews Management Gate Reviews are held at various points throughout the SDLC to ensure compliance with the NSF DIS SDLC policies and procedures and to ensure that the project is on time, within scope, and within budget. The figure below outlines the major management gate reviews, the contents to be reviewed, and the approvals required in order to proceed to the next phase. The project teams will determine in the initiation phase and agree with DIS leadership which gate reviews are required for the project. Figure 2: NSF DIS Management Gate Reviews

Gate

Gate Review Package Contents

Gate Review Approvals Required
Applications Architecture Operations Business Owner(s)*

Project Initiation Review

 Project Concept Briefing  High Level Project Schedule  Budget for Requirements Phase  Financial Structure (Provided by DIS PMO)  Management Briefing of Requirements

Requirements Review

(Including Communications Guidance (Mgt/Technical)  System Requirements Specification  Technical Implementation Strategy  Management Briefing of Design

Design Review Test Approach Review Test Results Review Pre-Deployment Review

 High Level Design  System Design Document  High Level Communications Strategy / Roll Out Plan  Management Briefing of Test Strategy / Approach  Requirements Traceability Matrix  Detailed Communications Plan  Management Briefing of Test Results  Security Testing Results  Readiness Review Briefing  Key Communications Materials (Promotional/Training)

* Business Owner(s) are defined on a per project basis Note: Refer to the CIP Roadmap Matrix for reviews/approvals required on detailed artifacts prior to the Management Gate Review

Page 5

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION

DIS SDLC Guide

3. SDLC Activities
The following sections specify the purpose, the sequence of activities and tasks to be initiated and completed within the SDLC along with the inputs, outputs, and tools available to support each task. 3.1 Planning & Initiation 3.1.1 Purpose The purpose of the Initiation Phase is to identify and define an opportunity to improve business operations for the organization. A plan is developed that documents the approach to be used and includes a discussion of methods, tools, tasks, resources, project schedules, and user input. Personnel assignments, costs, project schedule, and target dates are established. 3.1.2 Certification & Accreditation (C&A) Activities (If Major Application)  Input and Review of Project Concept Briefing

3.1.3 Required Deliverables      Project Concept Briefing Project Charter Project Management Plan High Level Project Schedule Budget for Requirements Phase

3.1.4 Other Artifacts   Concept of Operations Risk Management Plan

DIS SDLC Guide

Responsible Party Input Description

NSF and Industry information The following steps should be taken to complete this process step: 1. Gather NSF and industry information about the project idea/concept. Research similar existing projects and discuss potential options with subject matter experts. 2. Identify staff members to support the project concept/proposal process and identify sponsors. 3. Review potential approaches for performing the scope of work. 4. Perform initial project estimation for cost, effort, and size of the project. Document the basis of estimate. 5. Identify and document any project risks. 6. Determine Earned Value Management (EVM) requirements.

If modifications to the materials are requested, then the Project Team makes the necessary modifications and either conducts another in person review or conduct the review electronically. If the project concept is not approved, then the Project Team will not move forward with the project start up activities.

Page 15

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION 3.2 Requirements and Analysis Phase 3.2.1 Purpose

DIS SDLC Guide

The Requirements phase focuses on what the system will do in an effort that views all stakeholders, including sponsors and potential users, as important sources of information. During this phase you will:
  

Develop a high-level understanding of the stakeholders needs Define the detailed functional and non-functional requirements of the target process or system Provide an initial mapping of requirements for use in the design, development and testing lifecycles

3.2.2 Certification & Accreditation (C&A) Activities (If Major Application)
  

Conduct Preliminary Security Risk Assessment Information Categorization and Sensitivity Assessment Privacy Impact Assessment

3.2.3 Required Deliverables
 

System Requirements Specification Requirements Traceability Matrix

3.2.4 Other Artifacts
   

Business Requirements Wire Frames Other Supporting Requirements Documentation Communications Guidelines, Strategy, Plan

3.2.6 Requirements and Analysis Phase Process Details RA-01 Solicit Detailed Functional and Non-Functional Requirements Project Team

Responsible Party Input Description

Project Concept Briefing, Concept of Operations, Stakeholder Input Work with stakeholders to elicit needs, constraints, functional and non-functional requirements. Non-Functional Requirements such as security, performance, infrastructure and architecture, environment, flexibility and expansion, portability, maintainability and system administration requirements are typically gathered by meeting with subject matter experts within DIS and are gathered by the Technical Lead. Use requirements development methods, such as storyboarding and use cases, to begin development of requirements.

Tools Output

Requirements Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) Functional Requirements, Non-Functional Requirements

Page 17

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION RA-02

DIS SDLC Guide

Develop Business Requirements / Wireframes and Validate with Business Owner(s) Project Team

Responsible Party Input Description

Project Concept Briefing, Concept of Operations, Stakeholder Input Work with stakeholders to document business requirements and develop wireframes, if applicable. Requirements Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) Business Requirements, Wireframes

Tools Output

RA-03

Determine Security Requirements DIS Security Team

Responsible Party Input

Project Concept Briefing, Concept of Operations, Functional/Non-Functional Requirements Meet with the DIS IT Security Team to determine any and all security requirements. Analyze security requirements within the system security environment to include enterprise information security policy and enterprise security architecture. NSF Baseline Security Requirements, NIST Guidance System Security Requirements

Description

Tools Output

Page 18

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION RA-04 Conduct Preliminary Security Risk Assessment DIS Security Team

DIS SDLC Guide

Responsible Party Input

Project Concept Briefing, Concept of Operations, Functional Requirements, NonFunctional Requirements The DIS Security Team works with the Project Team to conduct a preliminary security risk assessment to establish an initial description of the basic security needs of the system. This assessment includes the Information Categorization and Sensitivity Assessment (ICSA). The DIS Security Team reviews the ICSA and determines if a Privacy Impact Assessment (PIA) is needed. If so, the Project Team creates the PIA and reviews it with the DIS Security Team. Information Categorization and Sensitivity Assessment Template Privacy Impact Assessment Template

Description

Tools

Output

Information Categorization and Sensitivity Assessment Privacy Impact Assessment

RA-05

Work with Project Team to Develop Communications Guidelines, Strategy, and Plan Communications Team

Responsible Party Input Description

Project Concept Briefing, Functional Requirements The Communications Team works with the Project Team to understand the project concept and high level requirements. The Communications Team elicits input from the project stakeholders and DIS Senior Management to develop an initial set of communications guidelines, a high level communications strategy and plan. N/A Communications guidelines, High Level Communications Strategy and Plan

Tools Output

Page 19

DIS SDLC Guide

Responsible Party Input

Page 21

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION RA-12 Conduct Requirements Gate Review DIS Senior Leadership / Business Owner

DIS SDLC Guide

Responsible Party Input Description

Management Gate Review Package The Project Team distributes the Gate Review package to the attendees in advance of the meeting. A meeting is conducted with the DIS Applications Lead, Architect, Operations, and Business Owner(s) to walk through the Requirements Briefing and the supporting gate review materials. The Project Team captures any key decisions or actions during the review meeting. The Gate Review process can also occur electronically via email if determined that an in person meeting is not necessary. N/A Key Decisions and Actions

Tools Output

RA-13

Requirements Approved? DIS Senior Leadership / Business Owner(s)

Responsible Party Input

Management Gate Review Package Key Decisions and Actions from Management Gate Review Meeting

Description

DIS Senior leadership and the Business Owner(s) determine whether the project requirements are approved and the project team can move forward with the design phase. If modifications to the requirements are requested, then the Project Team makes the necessary modifications and either conducts another in person review or conduct the review electronically.

Tools Output

N/A Decision on Project Requirements

Page 22

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION RA-14

DIS SDLC Guide

Obtain Approval for Requirements and Budget for Design Through Implementation DIS Senior Leadership / Business Owner(s)

Responsible Party Input Description

Decision on Project Requirements DIS Senior leadership and the Business Owner(s) provide approval to the Project Team to move forward with the design phase. N/A Approval to proceed

Tools Output

Page 24

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION 3.3 Design Phase 3.3.1 Purpose

DIS SDLC Guide

The Design phase focus defining the target architecture and application level design. The High Level Design defines the architecture components including the system reference architecture and deployment design. The system design document further elaborates on the architecture as well has the detailed system design including the class diagrams, sequence diagrams, and UI design. Additionally, the system design defines the data architecture including the logical and physical data models and the data dictionary. 3.3.2 Certification & Accreditation (C&A) (If Major Application)  System Security Plan

3.3.3 Required Deliverables    Technical Proposal High Level Design System Design Document

3.3.4 Other Artifacts  None

Page 25

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION 3.3.5 Process Flow
NSF DIS Design Phase Process Flow

DIS SDLC Guide

START

D-02 Develop the Technical Proposal

D-06 Develop High Level Design

D-01 Determine Whether to Build, Buy, or Reuse Components

D-03 Conduct Peer Review

D-07 Conduct Peer Review

D-12 Create Management Review Package

D-14 Develop System Design Document D-15 Conduct Peer Review

D-20 Baseline the SDD

D-21 Update the RTM

D-16 Conduct Quality Assurance Review

D-04 Conduct NSF Review

D-08 Conduct NSF Review

D-17 Conduct NSF Review

D-05 Conduct TaSS Review

D-09 Conduct TaSS Review
D-18 Major Application? No

D-10 Major Application? No

Yes

D-11 Begin System Security Plan

Yes

D-19 Update System Security Plan

D-13 Conduct Design Gate Review

END

Page 26

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION 3.3.6 Design Phase Process D-01 Determine whether to Build, Buy, or Reuse Components Responsible Party Input Description Project Team

DIS SDLC Guide

SRS, Technical Proposal Template      Research current NSF capabilities to find reusable components. Research past solutions to find reusable components. Perform market research to determine industry best practices and off-theshelf solutions. Schedule demos with selected vendors (if applicable). Evaluate technical capabilities of off-the-shelf solutions; including whether off-the-shelf solutions security controls meet technical security requirements as specified by project requirements and/or federal and NIST guidance (e.g. the National Information Assurance Partnership [NIAP] Common Criteria Evaluation and Validation Program) as outlined in NIST 800-23 Guidelines to Federal Organizations on Security Assurance and Acquisition/Use of Tested/Evaluated Products. Consult with the IT Security Team to determine the appropriate security baseline requirements. Survey current technical in-house capabilities to determine if capabilities exist to build the product. Perform cost-benefit analysis of building, buying, or reusing product components. Meet with TaSS to determine if a Technical Proposal or High-Level Design needs to be developed Document the technical solution decision using the Technical Proposal Template.

     Tools Output

Technical Proposal Template Draft Technical Solution

D-02

Develop the Technical Proposal Responsible Party Input Description Tools Output Project Team

Technical solution Project team prepares the Technical Proposal Technical Proposal Template Draft Technical Proposal

Page 27

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION D-03 Conduct Peer Review Responsible Party Input Description Project Team

DIS SDLC Guide

Technical Proposal Project team performs a peer review of the Technical Proposal that includes cross team technical architecture resources Peer Review Summary Report Template Peer Review Summary Report Template Updated Technical Proposal

Tools Output

D-04

NSF Project Lead Review Responsible Party Input Description NSF Project Lead

Technical Proposal The NSF Project Lead reviews the Technical Proposal and provides comments and feedback. The Project Team updates the Technical Proposal to address the NSF Lead comments

Tools Output

N/A Comments/Feedback on Technical Proposal Updated Technical Proposal

Page 28

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION D-05 TaSS Review Responsible Party Input Description TaSS

DIS SDLC Guide

Technical Proposal The purpose of the Technical Proposal is to present TaSS with the options considered for the project. This project could be an OLTP (web based) application, a COTS implementation, an infrastructure change or an enterprise service. The TaSS provides a recommendation based on alignment with NSF Enterprise Architecture and standard architecture guidelines. CIP Template: SDLC Tools -> Design -> Technical Proposal Template NSF Architecture Profile Target Reference Architecture (In Development)

Tools

Output

Comments/Feedback on Technical Proposal Updated Technical Proposal

D-06

Develop High Level Design Document Responsible Party Input Description Project Team

SRS, RTM, Approved Technical Proposal, High Level Design Template  Construct, expand, or reuse a service-oriented High-Level Design by analyzing inputs to develop, document, and maintain the high-level design including interfaces, and ensure the logical architecture is consistent with the TaSS developed System Reference Architecture (SRA). Design architecture in accordance with applicable standards. Re-use existing products, services and/or components where possible. Map product capabilities (environment, security, product, and interface requirements) and functional capabilities into services and/or components. Per the SRA, define/distinguish services vs. components for each piece of functionality. Document physical architecture/infrastructure Document the High-Level Design using the High-Level Design Template.

      Tools Output

CIP Template: SDLC Tools -> Design -> High Level Design Template Draft High Level Design

Page 29

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION D-07 Conduct Peer Review Responsible Party Input Description Project Team

DIS SDLC Guide

Draft High Level Design Project team performs a peer review of the High Level Design that includes cross team technical architecture resources. Project team incorporates any feedback/comments

Tools Output

Peer Review Summary Report Template Peer Review Summary Report Template Updated High Level Design

D-08

Conduct NSF Review Responsible Party Input Description NSF Project Lead

High Level Design NSF Project Lead performs review of the High Level Design and provides comments and feedback. Project Team incorporates NSF Project Lead comments/feedback

Tools Output

N/A Comments/Feedback on High Level Design Updated High Level Design

Page 30

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION D-09 Conduct TaSS Review Responsible Party Input Description TaSS

DIS SDLC Guide

High Level Design The High Level Design has to be based on the recommended option selected after the TaSS review of the Technical Proposal. TaSS reviews the High Level Design and provides recommendations for improvement and alignment with the Target Reference Architecture. TaSS will optionally create Change Requests to track any Action Items based on the review. The Project Team uses the Change Requests to incorporate TaSS comments/feedback.

Tools

NSF Architecture Profile Target Reference Architecture (In Development)

Output

Comments/Feedback on High Level Design Updated High Level Design

D-10

Major Application? Responsible Party Input Description DIS Security Team

Major Application Criteria DIS Security reviews the Information Categorization Form and High Level Design to determine whether the application meets the criteria for a major application. N/A Application categorized as major or minor

Tools Output

Page 31

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION D-11 Begin System Security Plan Responsible Party Input Description DIS Security Team

DIS SDLC Guide

Approved High Level Design If the application is categorized as a major application, then a System Security Plan is required. Based on the information in the High Level Design, the DIS Security Team creates the initial draft of the System Security Plan (SSP). The plan should define all aspects of system security (e.g. authentication process, level of access). SSP Template Draft SSP

Tools Output

D-12

Create Management Review Package Responsible Party Input Description Project Team

Technical Proposal; High Level Design; Design Review Briefing Template Project Team compiles the management review package for the Design Gate Review Design Review Briefing Template Management Gate Review Package

Tools Output

D-13

Conduct Design Gate Review Responsible Party Input Description DIS Senior Leadership / Business Owner

Management Gate Review Package Conduct review meeting with DIS Senior Management, Architect, Operations, and Business Owner(s). Capture any key decisions or actions during the review meeting. Design Review Briefing Template Key Decisions and Actions

Tools Output

Page 32

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION D-14 Develop System Design Document Responsible Party Input Project Team

DIS SDLC Guide

Approved High Level Design, SRS, RTM, Draft SSP, System Design Document (SDD) Template     Work with stakeholders to complete the design methodology, architecture, data architecture and application designs, including all relevant sub-sections like UI design, technical dependencies, and a data dictionary. Decompose High-Level design into the lowest level product components/services and ensure the logical architecture is consistent with the TaSS developed SRA. Design inter-component interfaces, user/system interfaces, database, and software/hardware interfaces. Draft the SDD using the SDD Template.

Description

Tools Output

SDD Template Draft SDD

Conduct Peer Review Responsible Party Input Description Project Team

Draft SDD Project team performs a peer review of the High Level Design that includes cross team technical architecture resources. Project team incorporates any feedback/comments

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION 3.4 Development Phase 3.4.1 Purpose

DIS SDLC Guide

The Development phase focuses on transforming the design into a working system that satisfies all the requirements. Any special procedures for data conversion and/or data warehousing will also be developed and tested during this phase. 3.4.2 Certification & Accreditation (C&A) Activities (If Major Application)  System Security Plan

3.4.3 Required Deliverables    Baselined Code Product Integration Document(s) Deployment Description Document

3.4.4 Other Artifacts   Unit Test Checklist Code Review Checklist

DEV-02 Develop Product Components

DEV-05 Conduct Unit Testing

DEV-08 Update Design Documents

DEV-09 Update the RTM

END

Page 44

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION T-07 Develop the Security Test and Evaluation Plan Responsible Party Input Description DIS Security Team

DIS SDLC Guide

Security Test and Evaluation (ST&E) Test Plan Template If the application is categorized as a major application or the enhancement is significantly modifying a major enhancement, then DIS Security will develop or modify the Security Test and Evaluation (ST&E) Plan.  If the project is adding a new component to a major application or significantly modifying a major application, review and update the appropriate Security Test and Evaluation Plan.  If this is a new development effort which has been classified by NSF Management as a Major Application or General Support System, DIS Security will prepare an ST&E Plan (to support Certification and Accreditation documentation if required). If the application is categorized as a minor application, then DIS Security will develop the ST&E to document the level of security testing that will be completed. ST&E Test Plan Template ST&E Test Plan

Tools Output

T-08

Refer to Existing Security Test and Evaluation Plan Responsible Party Input Description DIS Security Team

ST&E Plan for NSF Network and CCF If the application is categorized as a minor application, then DIS Security will refer the application to the ST&E for the NSF Network and CCF. DIS Security conducts a C&A of the NSF Network and CCF every three years. During the years that a C&A is not conducted, DIS Security conducts a technical controls review. ST&E Test Plan Template ST&E Test Plan

Tools Output

Page 45

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION T-09 Develop Test Cases / Test Scripts Responsible Party Input Project Team

DIS SDLC Guide

SRS, RTM, SDD, Test Plan, Notes from Joint Application Design (JAD) Sessions, Client Interviews and Change Requests.      Develop test cases/scripts for functional testing, which will be developed using Rational Test Manager Update test cases and functional test scripts using Manual Test and Test Manager. Record automated test scripts for regression testing - should not be recorded until system is stable. Record performance test scripts for performance testing - should not be recorded until system is stable. Refer to the Test Reference Guide for guidance on creating test scripts.

Description

Tools Output

Test Reference Guide Draft Test Cases / Scripts

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION T-15 Conduct Testing Responsible Party Input Description Project Team

DIS SDLC Guide

Test Cases/Scripts, Test Plan, CIP Test Strategy Guide  The project teams will conduct testing in the test environment using assigned test scripts. The types of testing typically can involve functional testing, performance testing, and usability testing. Additionally, as agreed to with the DIS Security Team, the Project Teams will conduct a preliminary application security scan of the environment. Document testing results - Test logs will be generated in Test Manager.

 Tools

Rational Test Manager, Manual Test, Functional Tester, Performance Tester, ClearCase, ClearQuest, WebInspect Test Results

Output

T-16

Output

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION DEP-03 Conduct Training and Demos Project Team

DIS SDLC Guide

Responsible Party Input Description

Stakeholder Support Documentation The Project Team will coordinate with the Learning Academy to determine what end user training is required. In addition to formal training, the Project Team should conduct system demos that are tailored to the specific divisions based on the SOPs. Additionally, the Project Team should train the IT Central Help Desk with an emphasis on what they expect to raise the most questions from end users. Lastly, the Project Team should conduct open demos that cover the basic functionality to provide end users multiple opportunities to understand the new functionality. NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION

DIS SDLC Guide

4. Appendix A: SDLC Artifacts by Phase and Required Reviews
Artifacts are the tools or "vehicle" used to support the needed work. Each phase of the process has artifacts that are associated with it (i.e. the Project Concept Briefing, Test Plan, etc.). These artifacts should not be viewed as sequential stepping stones in the development process, but rather, living documents that are open to modification throughout the entire life cycle. For example, the Project Concept document is among the first artifacts to be produced and reviewed by the project stakeholders, but it may need to be updated later in the Design phase when certain changes in direction may become necessary. The content provided in the SDLC artifacts is essential to the success of the project. As such, these project artifacts may be subjected to the Quality Assurance process. Individual sections should not be removed from the artifacts; however, additional data may be added based on the needs of the project. Each artifact should go through a review process prior to being approved. The table below lists the reviews required for each artifact by lifecycle phase prior to the management gate reviews.

Business Owner

Security Review

Phase

Artifact

Change Request Impact Analysis Concept of Operations Project Charter Release Summary Document Project Concept Briefing Project Management Plan Project Schedule System Requirements Specification Requirements Traceability Matrix High Level Design Technical Proposal System Design Document Master Test Plan Master Performance Test

Attachment E: Service Level Agreement Technical Requirements SLA Requirements
Req ID # Requirement Source Mandatory or Value-Added

SLA-01: Infrastructure Support SLA-01-01: General SLA-01-01-01 Additional products needed to meet the SLAs will be the responsibility of the contractor. The contractor will also be responsible for the production control functions of the systems. The contractor will provide the data network designed and built in accordance with industry best practices. The contractor will provide hardware, manage access to, and control the configuration of firewalls, switches, load balancers, and intrusion detection systems. The contractor must enforce the appropriate Configuration Management policies and practices as requested by NSF. The contractor shall honor NSF's requests to update or change access ports, Virtual IPs, and other configuration items. The contractor shall honor NSF's requests to update or change physical connectivity and changes to the physical network architecture as requested. NSF Requirement

SLA-01-04: Connectivity SLA-01-04-01 The proposed secure transmission facility must be compliant with Information Processing Standard (FIPS) 140-2. The contractor will also be responsible for the configuration and maintenance of each DNS entry for the servers. NSF will supply valid DNS names as required. VPN connections to the servers from any remote location needs to be within the secure internet tunnel. Secure internet tunnel" means a point to point Virtual Private Network (VPN) connection. A virtual private network (VPN) is a secure way of connecting to a private Local Area Network Network bandwidth requirements is 100K per user per second (for concurrent users) SLA-01-04-04 Additional network connections to selected recovery site only from selected primary site. NSF Requirement NSF Requirement

M

2

SLA-01-04-05

All connections entering the NSF selected network will possess a source Internet Protocol (IP) (TCP / IP) address range that is: a) An American Registry of Internet Numbers (ARIN) registered address, b) Registered to the customer (NSF) The IP address will be registered to the customer or related to the customer by reference from the IP address owner. Connectivity entering the selected network will pass through several layers of network and server-based controls including Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS), packet filtering systems, and proxy filtering systems, as appropriate.

SLA-02: Application Management SLA-02-01: Software SLA-02-01-01 The contractor will be responsible for the administration of the COTS. The Contractor's responsibility for application trouble-shooting includes providing troubleshooting logs and other data, restarts/recycling. The Contractor will make every reasonable effort to remain current with all software versions, patches or new releases. Appropriate testing is required to ensure that business functionality is not compromised by updates. Patching and version upgrade functions for infrastructure software components will be done by the Contractor. Planned upgrades must be communicated to NSF in advance so they can complete regression testing prior to changes being implemented. NSF Requirement NSF Requirement

M

SLA-02-01-02

M

SLA-02-01-03

NSF Requirement

M

SLA-02-02: Configuration Management

3

SLA-02-02-01

The contractor would provide a Configuration and Change Management Plan and gain approval from NSF. The Change Management Plan will include a description of how the contractor will inform NSF of all changes applied to the system. Changes to the User Interface and the system interfaces to the NSF applications need to be approved by NSF at time when changes are identified and prioritized. The contractor will maintain standard process and documentation for any functional changes. An impact analysis document should be maintained for every change. All changes would be implemented only upon approval from NSF. The contractor should maintain a tool to capture version control and changes to the base requirements. The contractor is responsible for the software, licenses, and maintenance of the tool. The contractor will provide the required audit information to NSF. The Contractor should plan with appropriate documentation on all software upgrade, modifications, patches or any other system changes and get approval on the Release schedule from NSF. The Contractor shall certify applications are fully functional and operate correctly as intended on systems using the US Government Configuration Baseline (USGCB) (formerly Federal Desktop Core Configuration (FDCC)). The USGCB common security configurations are available from the National Institute of Standards and Technology's Web site at http://checklists.nist.gov . Applications designed for normal end users shall run in the standard user context without elevated privileges.

NSF Requirement

SLA-02-02-07

The Contractor shall implement software implementation, operation, maintenance, update, and/or patching in a manner that does not alter the configuration settings from the NSF approved configurations. The contractor will regularly provide NSF the detailed list of the implemented Production requests. Where a system or application is approaching the End of Service Life (EOSL), where the vendor will no longer support the software or equipment, the Contractor will prepare a plan to migrate to a supported platform or version. NSF will review the plan and approve it, or request modifications.

SLA-03: System Performance SLA-03-01: Capacity SLA-03-01-01 System should support 561 individual and 100 concurrent users with a minimum of 4000 transactions a day. The contractor shall provide an incremental approach to adding users and costs. NSF Requirement

M

SLA-03-02: Availability SLA-03-02-01 The system will be available 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. (99.95 % uptime for production) with the exception of scheduled down time agreed upon between the contractor and the NSF. Planned outages should be communicated to NSF at least six weeks in advance. Monitoring and metric reporting will be done by the contractor. System performance and metric data must be provided to NSF on a regular basis. NSF Requirement

M

SLA-03-02-02

NSF Requirement NSF Requirement

M M

SLA-03-02-03

5

SLA-03-02-04

Planned downtime must not correspond with core business hours of the iTRAK Users, 7 a.m. EST to 8 p.m. EST Monday through Friday or during end of fiscal year processing.

NSF Requirement

M

SLA-03-03: Integration SLA-03-03-01 Each business transaction should be processed in iTRAK and sent back to the NSF systems with 2 seconds on a near real-time scenario. In a near real-time scenario, upon failure to communicate the response to NSF systems, the system should make 5 consecutive tries within a duration of 60 seconds before throwing any exceptions. iTRAK should provide proper reconciliation reports for all business transactions through the interface. The interfaces should be available 24x7x365 except on planned outages. The interfaces should be able to support 50 concurrent transactions without performance degradation. All changes to the interfaces endpoints should be documented and communicated to NSF at least 8 weeks in advance. The data load from iTRAK to NSF staging area should happen on a daily basis (every 24 hours) or near/real time or on demand basis. Supporting documentation (data dictionary, data model) on the data should be provided to NSF. Any planned outages should be notified to NSF at least 6 weeks in advance. All production incidents should be responded with 2 hours. The incidents should be NSF Requirement

M

SLA-03-03-02

NSF Requirement

M

NSF Requirement
