SECTION E SOLICITATION PROVISIONS E.1 SOLICITATION PROVISIONS INCORPORATED BY REFERENCE FAR 52.212-1 Instructions to Offerors ­ Commercial Items (JUN 2008) (See addendum) FAR 52.234-3 Notice of Earned Value Management System ­ Post Award IBR (JUL 2006) E.2 FAR 52.212-3 OFFEROR REPRESENTATIONS AND CERTIFICATIONS-COMMERCIAL ITEMS (MAY 2011) An offeror shall complete only paragraph (b) of this provision if the offeror has completed the annual representations and certifications electronically at http://orca.bpn.gov. If an offeror has not completed the annual representations and certifications electronically at the ORCA website, the offeror shall complete only paragraphs (c) through (o) of this provision. (a) Definitions. As used in this provision-- "Economically disadvantaged women-owned small business (EDWOSB) concern" means a small business concern that is at least 51 percent directly and unconditionally owned by, and the management and daily business operations of which are controlled by, one or more women who are citizens of the United States and who are economically disadvantaged in accordance with 13 CFR part 127. It automatically qualifies as a women-owned small business eligible under the WOSB Program. "Forced or indentured child labor" means all work or service-- (1) Exacted from any person under the age of 18 under the menace of any penalty for its nonperformance and for which the worker does not offer himself voluntarily; or (2) Performed by any person under the age of 18 pursuant to a contract the enforcement of which can be accomplished by process or penalties. "Inverted domestic corporation", as used in this section, means a foreign incorporated entity which is treated as an inverted domestic corporation under 6 U.S.C. 395(b), i.e., a corporation that used to be incorporated in the United States, or used to be a partnership in the United States, but now is incorporated in a foreign country, or is a subsidiary whose parent corporation is incorporated in a foreign country, that meets the criteria specified in 6 U.S.C. 395(b), applied in accordance with the rules and definitions of 6 U.S.C. 395(c). An inverted domestic corporation as herein defined does not meet the definition of an inverted domestic corporation as defined by the Internal Revenue Code at 26 U.S.C. 7874. "Manufactured end product" means any end product in Federal Supply Classes (FSC) 1000 -9999, except-- (1) FSC 5510, Lumber and Related Basic Wood Materials; (2) Federal Supply Group (FSG) 87, Agricultural Supplies; (3) FSG 88, Live Animals; (4) FSG 89, Food and Related Consumables; (5) FSC 9410, Crude Grades of Plant Materials; (6) FSC 9430, Miscellaneous Crude Animal Products, Inedible; (7) FSC 9440, Miscellaneous Crude Agricultural and Forestry Products; (8) FSC 9610, Ores; (9) FSC 9620, Minerals, Natural and Synthetic; and
Page 24

(10) FSC 9630, Additive Metal Materials. "Place of manufacture" means the place where an end product is assembled out of components, or otherwise made or processed from raw materials into the finished product that is to be provided to the Government. If a product is disassembled and reassembled, the place of reassembly is not the place of manufacture. "Restricted business operations" means business operations in Sudan that include power production activities, mineral extraction activities, oil-related activities, or the production of military equipment, as those terms are defined in the Sudan Accountability and Divestment Act of 2007 (Pub. L. 110-174). Restricted business operations do not include business operations that the person (as that term is defined in Section 2 of the Sudan Accountability and Divestment Act of 2007) conducting the business can demonstrate-- (1) Are conducted under contract directly and exclusively with the regional government of southern Sudan; (2) Are conducted pursuant to specific authorization from the Office of Foreign Assets Control in the Department of the Treasury, or are expressly exempted under Federal law from the requirement to be conducted under such authorization; (3) Consist of providing goods or services to marginalized populations of Sudan; (4) Consist of providing goods or services to an internationally recognized peacekeeping force or humanitarian organization; (5) Consist of providing goods or services that are used only to promote health or education; or (6) Have been voluntarily suspended. "Service-disabled veteran-owned small business concern"-- (1) Means a small business concern-- (i) Not less than 51 percent of which is owned by one or more service-disabled veterans or, in the case of any publicly owned business, not less than 51 percent of the stock of which is owned by one or more service-disabled veterans; and (ii) The management and daily business operations of which are controlled by one or more service-disabled veterans or, in the case of a service-disabled veteran with permanent and severe disability, the spouse or permanent caregiver of such veteran. (2) Service-disabled veteran means a veteran, as defined in 38 U.S.C. 101(2), with a disability that is service-connected, as defined in 38 U.S.C. 101(16). "Small business concern" means a concern, including its affiliates, that is independently owned and operated, not dominant in the field of operation in which it is bidding on Government contracts, and qualified as a small business under the criteria in 13 CFR Part 121 and size standards in this solicitation. "Subsidiary" means an entity in which more than 50 percent of the entity is owned -- (1) Directly by a parent corporation; or (2) Through another subsidiary of a parent corporation. "Veteran-owned small business concern" means a small business concern--

Page 25

(1) Not less than 51 percent of which is owned by one or more veterans (as defined at 38 U.S.C. 101(2)) or, in the case of any publicly owned business, not less than 51 percent of the stock of which is owned by one or more veterans; and (2) The management and daily business operations of which are controlled by one or more veterans. "Women-owned business concern" means a concern which is at least 51 percent owned by one or more women; or in the case of any publicly owned business, at least 51 percent of its stock is owned by one or more women; and whose management and daily business operations are controlled by one or more women. "Women-owned small business concern" means a small business concern-- (1) That is at least 51 percent owned by one or more women; or, in the case of any publicly owned business, at least 51 percent of the stock of which is owned by one or more women; and (2) Whose management and daily business operations are controlled by one or more women. "Women-owned small business (WOSB) concern eligible under the WOSB Program" (in accordance with 13 CFR part 127), means a small business concern that is at least 51 percent directly and unconditionally owned by, and the management and daily business operations of which are controlled by, one or more women who are citizens of the United States. Page 31

(h) Certification Regarding Responsibility Matters (Executive Order 12689). (Applies only if the contract value is expected to exceed the simplified acquisition threshold.) The offeror certifies, to the best of its knowledge and belief, that the offeror and/or any of its principals -- (1) o Are, o are not presently debarred, suspended, proposed for debarment, or declared ineligible for the award of contracts by any Federal agency; (2) o Have, o have not, within a three-year period preceding this offer, been convicted of or had a civil judgment rendered against them for: commission of fraud or a criminal offense in connection with obtaining, attempting to obtain, or performing a Federal, state or local government contract or subcontract; violation of Federal or state antitrust statutes relating to the submission of offers; or commission of embezzlement, theft, forgery, bribery, falsification or destruction of records, making false statements, tax evasion, violating Federal criminal tax laws, or receiving stolen property; (3) o Are, o are not presently indicted for, or otherwise criminally or civilly charged by a Government entity with, commission of any of these offenses enumerated in paragraph (h)(2) of this clause; and (4) o Have, o have not, within a three-year period preceding this offer, been notified of any delinquent Federal taxes in an amount that exceeds $3,000 for which the liability remains unsatisfied. (i) Taxes are considered delinquent if both of the following criteria apply: (A) The tax liability is finally determined. The liability is finally determined if it has been assessed. A liability is not finally determined if there is a pending administrative or judicial challenge. In the case of a judicial challenge to the liability, the liability is not finally determined until all judicial appeal rights have been exhausted. (B) The taxpayer is delinquent in making payment. A taxpayer is delinquent if the taxpayer has failed to pay the tax liability when full payment was due and required. A taxpayer is not delinquent in cases where enforced collection action is precluded. (ii) Examples. (A) The taxpayer has received a statutory notice of deficiency, under I.R.C. §6212, which entitles the taxpayer to seek Tax Court review of a proposed tax deficiency. This is not a delinquent tax because it is not a final tax liability. Should the taxpayer seek Tax Court review, this will not be a final tax liability until the taxpayer has exercised all judicial appeal rights. (B) The IRS has filed a notice of Federal tax lien with respect to an assessed tax liability, and the taxpayer has been issued a notice under I.R.C. §6320 entitling the taxpayer to request a hearing with the IRS Office of Appeals contesting the lien filing, and to further appeal to the Tax Court if the IRS determines to sustain the lien filing. In the course of the hearing, the taxpayer is entitled to contest the underlying tax liability because the taxpayer has had no prior opportunity to contest the liability. This is not a delinquent tax because it is not a final tax liability. Should the taxpayer seek tax court review, this will not be a final tax liability until the taxpayer has exercised all judicial appeal rights. (C) The taxpayer has entered into an installment agreement pursuant to I.R.C. §6159. The taxpayer is making timely payments and is in full compliance with the agreement terms. The taxpayer is not delinquent because the taxpayer is not currently required to make full payment.
Page 32

(D) The taxpayer has filed for bankruptcy protection. The taxpayer is not delinquent because enforced collection action is stayed under 11 U.S.C. §362 (the Bankruptcy Code). (i) Certification Regarding Knowledge of Child Labor for Listed End Products (Executive Order 13126). (ii) The services will be furnished at prices which are, or are based on, established catalog or market prices (see FAR 22.1003-4(c)(2)(ii)) for the maintenance, calibration, or repair of such equipment; and (iii) The compensation (wage and fringe benefits) plan for all service employees performing work under the contract will be the same as that used for these employees and equivalent employees servicing the same equipment of commercial customers. [ ] (2) Certain services as described in FAR 22.1003-4(d)(1). The offeror_____does____does not certify that-- (i) The services under the contract are offered and sold regularly to non-Governmental customers, and are provided by the offeror (or subcontractor in the case of an exempt subcontract) to the general public in substantial quantities in the course of normal business operations; (ii) The contract services will be furnished at prices that are, or are based on, established catalog or market prices (see FAR 22.1003-4(d)(2)(iii)); (iii) Each service employee who will perform the services under the contract will spend only a small portion of his or her time (a monthly average of less than 20 percent of the available hours on an annualized basis, or less than 20 percent of available hours during the contract period if the contract period is less than a month) servicing the Government contract; and (iv) The compensation (wage and fringe benefits) plan for all service employees performing work under the contract is the same as that used for these employees and equivalent employees servicing commercial customers. (3) If paragraph (k)(1) or (k)(2) of this clause applies-- (i) If the offeror does not certify to the conditions in paragraph (k)(1) or (k)(2) and the Contracting Officer did not attach a Service Contract Act wage determination to the solicitation, the offeror shall notify the Contracting Officer as soon as possible; and (ii) The Contracting Officer may not make an award to the offeror if the offeror fails to execute the certification in paragraph (k)(1) or (k)(2) of this clause or to contact the Contracting Officer as required in paragraph (k)(3)(i) of this clause. (l) Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN) (26 U.S.C. 6109, 31 U.S.C. 7701). (Not applicable if the offeror is required to provide this information to a central contractor registration database to be eligible for award.) (1) All offerors must submit the information required in paragraphs (l)(3) through (l)(5) of this provision to comply with debt collection requirements of 31 U.S.C. 7701(c) and 3325(d), reporting requirements of 26 U.S.C. 6041, 6041A, and 6050M, and implementing regulations issued by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). (2) The TIN may be used by the Government to collect and report on any delinquent amounts arising out of the offeror's relationship with the Government (31 U.S.C. 7701(c)(3)). If the resulting contract is subject to the payment reporting requirements described in FAR 4.904, the TIN provided hereunder may be matched with IRS records to verify the accuracy of the offeror's TIN. (4) Type of organization. o Sole proprietorship; o Partnership; o Corporate entity (not tax-exempt); o Corporate entity (tax-exempt); o Government entity (Federal, State, or local); o Foreign government; o International organization per 26 CFR 1.6049-4; o Other ________________________________. (2) The certification requirement of paragraph (o)(1) of this provision does not apply if-- (i) This solicitation includes a trade agreements certification (e.g., 52.212-3(g) or a comparable agency provision); and (ii) The offeror has certified that all the offered products to be supplied are designated country end products. E.3 FAR 52.212-1 INSTRUCTIONS TO OFFERORS--COMMERCIAL ITEMS (ADDENDUM) VOLUME/PROPOSAL SECTION PAGE LIMIT Offerors are cautioned to follow the instructions provided carefully to assure the Government receives consistent information in a form that will facilitate proposal evaluation. Text shall be single-spaced, on 8 1/2 x 11 inch paper with 12 point, Times New Roman font (except as specifically noted), with a minimum one-inch margin all around. Pages shall be numbered consecutively within each volume. The Government will only evaluate to the maximum number of pages allowed for each Volue (see below). Each volume in the proposal shall include a copy of the cover letter (letter of transmittal), a title page and a table of contents. The table of contents shall list sections, subsections, and page numbers. The cover letter, title page, and table of contents do not count against the page limitation. 1. Volume I: Technical (Applicable for the overall IDIQ contract and Task Order 1)- A written technical description shall be submitted to address overall IDIQ requirements and segregated to describe requirements for completing tasks as identified Task Order 1. Volume I shall be segregated as follows: (a) Overall IDIQ Contract Technical Requirements Section: 40 pages maximum (excluding Service Level Agreement) (b) Task Order 1 Technical Requirements Section: 30 pages maximum Note: Task Order 1 (Implementation and Integration Services) will be awarded in conjunction with the IDIQ contract. 2. Volume II: Management Approach (Applicable for the overall IDIQ contract and Task Order 1)- A written description shall be submitted to address the Management Approach for the overall IDIQ contract and segregated for Task Order 1 requirements. Management Approach Page Limitation: 30 pages maximum; Resumes: 2 pages maximum per Key Personnel (excluding letters of commitment) 3. Volume III: Past Performance (Applicable for the Overall IDIQ contract and Task Order 1): 6 pages maximum 4. Volume IV: IDIQ Price Proposal: No Page Limit 5. Volume V: Extent of Participation of Small Disadvantage Business Concerns: 6. Volume VI: Task Order 1 Business Proposal: No page limit 10 pages maximum

7. PowerPoint Slides (pdf): A maximum of 30 PowerPoint Presentation slides shall be submitted with the Proposal for subsequent presentation during the oral proposals, and covering the information as identified in this RFP.

Offerors shall not include any pricing information in non-price volumes (Volumes I, II, and III). information included in these volumes will not be considered by the Government.

E.4 SOLICITATION (RFP) QUESTIONS DUE Any Offeror desiring an explanation or interpretation of the solicitation is instructed to submit their questions via email no later than 15 days after the issuance date of this solicitation to tfrazier@nsf.gov. Offerors are notified that proposals including exceptions to contract terms and conditions, requests for resources or property in addition to those stated in the solicitation, or including any and all other types of changes, exceptions, or "assumptions" pertaining to Government requirements, may make their proposal ineligible for award. All such matters shall be addressed by the Offeror by requesting an explanation or interpretation of the solicitation as set forth in this clause. E.5 OFFEROR RESPONSIBILITY FOR ALL PROPOSAL COSTS Offerors are advised that the Government is not responsible for, and will not pay or reimburse, any costs incurred by the Offeror in the development or submission of any aspect of their proposal under this solicitation. This includes costs associated with any aspect of the proposal activity and any research, studies, or designs carried out for the purpose of incorporation into any part of the offer. It also includes any costs to acquire or contract for any services or products relating to the proposal under this solicitation. E.6 PROPOSAL DUE DATE Proposals must be submitted electronically by 12:00PM Eastern Standard Time on November 30, 2011 to Thurl Frazier, Contracting Officer at tfrazier@nsf.gov E.7 INSTRUCTIONS FOR ORAL PRESENTATION AND SOFTWARE DEMONSTRATION (a) Offerors must submit their oral presentation materials together with their proposals in Portable Document Format (PDF). Offerors may not change their presentation after this submission. The purpose of this restriction is to protect the integrity of the oral presentation process. Offerors shall mark their package containing their presentation materials for the oral presentation as follows: Offeror's (by name) presentation material for the iTRAK Oral Presentation. (b) The oral presentation shall be conducted using Microsoft Powerpoint and cover the exact information that was provided in the previously submitted PDF presentation materials. (c )The oral presentation shall only address the items that are identified as "Oral Presentation" in the applicable Technical subfactors. (d) Within (15) calendar days after the closing date of the RFP, each offeror who submits a responsive proposal and which is received by the designated proposal due date and time will be given the date, time, and room number for their oral presentation. The oral presentation will be conducted at NSF Headquarters in Arlington, Virginia and the Government will randomly assign a date and time for the oral presentation to each Offeror. The right to reschedule any Offeror's presentation is at the discretion of the Contracting Officer. (e) Submission of videotapes or other forms of video contained in the presentation for evaluation in lieu of the oral presentation will not be authorized and will be rejected. Only members of the offeror's proposed key personnel shall participate in the oral presentation.

Page 37

(f) The length of the oral presentation shall be no more than 90 minutes and compliant with all mandatory instructions contained in this solicitation. (g) Offeror's shall not provide any additional written material during the presentation. No external communication (cellular phone, phone calls, email, etc.) shall be permitted during the oral presentation period. (h) incorporation by reference of oral statements is not permitted during the presentation. Offerors are advised to ensure that their slides are complete and comprehensive, and cover all the areas subject to their oral presentation. (i) The oral presentation shall not constitute discussions as defined in FAR 15. 306(d). (j) In addition, Offerors shall conduct software demonstrations of the proposed COTS solution during the oral presentation. Offerors will be allotted an additional 60 minutes for software demonstrations and shall be conducted after the 90 minute period of the oral presentation. Offerors shall conduct software demonstrations for specific NSF and Federal iTRAK Business Requirements (Attachment B) for the following items in the order of which they appear: Procure to Pay; Inter-Agency Agreements; Financial Statement Process; and Reporting tools that are standard with the software Note: The information provided during the software demonstrations shall be used by the Government as information for the purpose of evaluating Subfactor A, Technical Approach. NSF will provide access to the intenet, a projector, and other audio equipment for the software demonstration and oral presentation. The expected format of the presentation is shown below: Description Presentation Break Software Demonstration Time Limit 90 Minutes 15 Minutes 60 Minutes

Please note that the Offeror will be limited to the time limits set forth above and must plan their Presentation and Software Demonstration Accordingly. The Government will immediately cut-off presentations that exceed these time limits. There will be no questions by the Government during the presentation or Software Demonstration. The maximum number of Offeror participants during the Oral Presentation and Software Demonstration is 8.

Page 38

E.8 Factor 1: Technical (Volume I) Volume I shall consist of the Offeror's Technical capabilities for the overall IDIQ contract and Task Order 1 requirements in response to this RFP. The Offeror shall provide a total solution that includes financial management software and implementation and integration services to include project management and organizational change management, hosting, operations and maintenance, enhancement services, and transaction service that addresses all of the objectives and requirements in the RFP. Subfactor A: Technical Approach The Offeror shall address the following minimum information in the Technical Approach section of Volume I: a) Provide a description of the proposed financial system's overall functional and technical capabilities with particular emphasis on any pre-configured functionality provided by the Offeror; b) Describe how the solution meets Federal Financial System requirements and will address all NSF specific mandatory requirements identified in Attachment B, iTRAK Business Requirements; Complete Attachment B, in the Master Requirements List, indicating a "yes" or "no" in the column titled "Software Meets Requirements Out Of The Box?" Explain any "no" responses in the "comments" column. c) Provide information on the specific Core Financial functionality and system features that support NSF's financial management processes; d) Written, Software Demonstration and Oral Presentation- Provide detailed description on how the First-in-First-Out Process will be accomplished. Specifically, discuss the process used to design, develop, and deploy a custom cost allocation methodology as part of the iTRAK solution. Discuss how the deployed cost allocation methodology will meet the requirements as identified in Attachment B, iTRAK Business Requirements, "Cost Allocation Requirements" section and be used to allocate grant expenditure costs across amendments and splits on individual grant awards. Offerors shall describe the "Procure to Pay" process from entry of a purchase order through the invoice payment. Offerors shall describe the "Inter-Agency Agreement (IAA)" process (in-coming and out-going) for tracking an IAA in the financial system to include commitments, obligations, expenditures, and how IPAC (Intragovernmental Payment) transactions are recorded. Offerors shall describe the financial system's capabilities for processing financial statements to include but not limited to formatting, ability to export data, and flexibility in changes to accommodate NSF's reporting requirements. Offerors shall also describe the reporting tools that are standard with the software. e) Written and Oral Presentation- Specifically, discuss the accounting reconciliation process performed at the individual transaction level and at the summary level for period end closing. Discuss any specific tools or accelerators that are proposed. The Offeror shall also discuss in detail the purchase card process (from identification of need to payment to reconciliation and closeout. Discuss any specific tools that will be utilized to conduct this process. f) Include a statement and any supporting information or documentation that demonstrates that all proposed software products are compliant with Federal Financial System requirements and OMB Memo M-10-26 and will be supported throughout the contract period of performance. "Supported" is defined here as continued compliance with Federal financial system requirements and any legislative,
Page 39

Office of Management and Budget (OMB), Department of Treasury, or other federal mandates affecting financial management and reporting requirements that are enacted or promulgated after award of this contract. g) Provide a list of the standard reports, queries, and preconfigured workflows that are standard in the proposed solution; h) Provide the estimated schedule for major release upgrades over the contract period of performance; and i) Describe the methodology for remaining current against any future Federal requirements or mandates.

Subfactor B: Implementation Services The Offeror shall provide a description of the implementation services, which shall include, at a minimum, discussion of the following: a) The proposed implementation schedule, including all dependent and concurrent tasks. The schedule provided shall support full operational capability of the new financial system in a hosted environment by October 1, 2013. All financial reports will be available October 1, 2013; b) The strategy for working with NSF to configure and fully implement by October 1, 2013; c) The system configuration methodology; d) The testing methodology for implementation; e) A description for developing and implementing a new chart of accounts; f) The methodology for software release management; g) The data conversion and migration methodology; and h) The documentation processes and procedures and the specific documents that will be developed and delivered to NSF. Subfactor C: Integration with NSF Systems Written and Oral Presentation- The Offeror shall provide a description of the integration services for interfaces with NSF systems, which shall include, at a minimum, discussion of the following: a) The strategy for working with NSF to develop NSF interfaces by October 1, 2013; b) The system interface development methodology for integration with NSF systems; c) The testing methodology for integration with NSF systems; and d) The specific interface documents that will be developed and delivered to NSF. Subfactor D: Integration with Federal Systems Written and Oral Presentation- The Offeror shall provide a description of the integration services for interfaces with Federal systems, which shall include, at a minimum, discussion of the following: a) The strategy for working with NSF to develop Federal interfaces by October 1, 2013; b) The system interface development methodology for integration with Federal systems; c) The testing methodology for integration with federal systems; and d) The specific interface documents that will be developed and delivered to NSF.
Page 40

Subfactor E: Hosting Services During Implementation The Offeror shall provide a detailed description of the hosting services for implementation and integration to support solution development. The description provided shall address, at a minimum: a) The proposed development model describing at a minimum the environments for configuration, integration, staging, data migration and conversion, all testing and training; b) The enterprise COTS license solution, versions available, and all warranties, terms and conditions; and c) The security management and access control for the environments. Subfactor F: Organizational Change Management & Training The Offeror shall provide a detailed description of the organizational change management and training services support solution deployment at NSF. The description provided shall address, at a minimum: a) The proposed organizational change management methodology to include at a minimum communication and transition activities for moving users from the old system to the new system; and b) The proposed training methodology to include at a minimum training development methodology, training delivery methodology, and proposed training schedule. Subfactor G: Hosting (Post Implementation) The Offeror shall provide a detailed description of the hosting services proposed to support and host the proposed solution, consistent with the goals and objectives of Federal financial system requirements. The description provided shall address, at a minimum: a)The proposed hosting model, including recommending a shared or single instance of the proposed financial system, proposed hardware, software, and maintenance plan; b)The proposed plan for transitioning to production; c) The design for end user access and points of connection; d) The user support methodology, tools, and reporting mechanisms that will satisfy the objectives described in the PWS, including recommended user issue and inquiry response performance objectives (severity levels and definitions, escalation criteria), standard, and performance threshold; e) The methodology for Continuity of Operations and Disaster Recovery; f) The methodology to proactively managing and mitigating security risks throughout the duration of the contract. The methodology shall include the identification of major risks encountered on similar projects and how the proposed methodology mitigates those risks; and g) The Service Level Agreement (SLA), which shall be included in its entirety in Volume I. The SLA shall describe the specific methodology for hosting and IT administration performance measurement. The Offeror shall describe its methodology for proposing updates to the SLA and addressing performance deficiencies per the SLA. The SLA shall identify the specific services and support that will be provided to NSF with regard to the hosting support of the financial system. The SLA shall establish service levels, metrics, monitoring methods and organizational responsibilities. The Offeror shall ensure that the performance metrics listed in the proposed SLA align with the information metrics included in the
Page 41

Offeror's QCP and the performance requirements metrics identified in Attachments C (Interface Requirements), Implementation and Integration Performance Standards, and Attachment E (SLA Requirements).

Subfactor H: Operations & Maintenance Services The Offeror shall describe their methodology for providing the software and services for running and managing access to the proposed system and the interfaces with feeder systems that exchange data with the Core Financial system. The Offeror's response shall: a) Describe the scope of operations and maintenance services and the methodologies and tools used to support those services; b) Discuss the architecture and other technical elements that comprise the proposed solution's technical environment (e.g., Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) enablement, scalability, ability to integrate with other commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) products and legacy systems, development tools, etc.); c) Describe the methodology for staying up-to-date with current versions of the software (patches, releases, upgrades) and the planned schedule for release and upgrades; d) Describe the methodology for testing software upgrades and releases; and e) Include a statement and any supporting information or documentation that demonstrates that all proposed software products are compliant with Federal Financial System requirements and OMB Memo M-10-26 and will be supported for the term of the contract period of performance. "Supported" is defined here as continued compliance with Federal financial system requirements and any legislative, OMB, Treasury or other federal mandates affecting financial management and reporting requirements that are enacted or promulgated after award of this contract; f) Describe the system change control management processes and procedures to include explanations of how hosted customers are included in the process and how it is determined what new functionality will be incorporated into future releases; g) Provide the estimated schedule for major release upgrades over the period of performance for this contract; h) Describe the methodology for remaining current against any future federal requirements or mandates; i) Describe Tier I, II and III help desk support including proposed escalation criteria, response times, and performance metrics; and h) Describe the Service Level Agreement (SLA), which shall be included in its entirety in Volume I. The SLA shall describe the specific methodology for operations and maintenance performance measurement. The Offeror shall describe its methodology for proposing updates to the SLA and addressing performance deficiencies per the SLA. The SLA shall identify the specific services and support that will be provided to NSF with regard to the operations and maintenance support of the financial system. The SLA shall establish service levels, metrics, monitoring methods and organizational responsibilities. The Offeror shall ensure that the performance metrics listed in the proposed SLA align with the information metrics included in the Offeror's QCP and the performance requirements metrics identified in Attachments C (Interface Requirements), Implementation and Integration Performance Standards, and Attachment E (SLA Requirements).

Page 42

Subfactor I: Transition Services The Offeror shall describe their methodology for working with NSF and a successor contractor at the end of the period of performance to continue services and execute an orderly and efficient transition for Hosting, Operations and Maintenance, and Business Support Services, if needed. Subfactor J: Enhancement Services The Offeror shall describe their methodology for working with NSF to develop and implement enhancements. Subfactor K: Business Process Support Services The Offeror shall describe their methodology for providing financial transaction processing for requirements described in the PWS. The methodology shall include the organizational structure as well as how the Offeror will communicate with NSF. Factor 2: Management Approach (Volume II) Volume II shall describe the Offeror's planned methodology for managing the execution of its solution for the IDIQ contract and Task Order 1 requirements. At a minimum, the Management Approach shall include the following: a) Project Management. The Offeror shall provide a description of the proposed methodologies and tools that will be utilized by the Offeror for the management and execution of the Offeror's solution. This includes, at a minimum, the following: 1. Project management methodologies, including any certifications that the Offeror's organization has and will apply to this work. Such methodologies shall address, at a minimum, the following project management areas: i. ii. iii. iv. v. vi. vii. viii. ix. Project start-up methodology; Schedule management; Scope management; Project financial management using Earned Value Management; Document Management; Requirements management; Configuration management; Software Change Management; Status Reporting

2. Methodology for collaborating with NSF or NSF contractors, including an explanation of communication strategies and processes for identifying and resolving problems. b) Project Schedule. The Offeror shall describe the proposed tasks that the Offeror will perform to satisfy all of NSF's objectives within the 18-month implementation time line. The project schedule shall highlight the sequence of events that the Offeror will use to fulfill the proposed objectives and
Page 43

requirements, consistent with the Offeror's proposed pricing. This project schedule shall allow NSF to clearly identify and understand the proposed methodology, tasks, and timeframes. Note: Offerors shall also propose a "Schedule of Deliverables" table within the project schedule for all deliverables that are identified in Task Order 1. This table shall include due dates for all deliverables with submission to the NSF Contracting Offi cer's Technical Representative. c) Risk Management. The Offeror shall describe its proposed methodology to proactively managing and mitigating project risks throughout the duration of the contract, from pre-implementation to operations and maintenance. The methodology shall include the identification of major risks encountered on similar projects and how the proposed methodology mitigates those risks. d) Quality Control Plan (QCP). The Offeror shall include a description of the methodology, processes, data collection systems, tools, techniques, and resources that the Offeror proposes to effectively manage the delivery of products and services that meet or exceed the objectives described in the RFP. The QCP shall describe the Offeror's systematic method for providing confidence that the Offeror's products and services are developed and delivered according to established processes and are of the highest quality. It shall define the policy for quality control activities, the organizational structure of the quality control group, roles and responsibilities of the quality control group, and a schedule for reviews and audits. The proposed methodology shall provide NSF with complete visibility and unrestricted self-service access to quality control review and audit results. e) CIP Documentation Support. The Offeror shall include a description of the methodology for supporting reviews for the NSF CIP process as well as briefings and meetings with NSF's governance structure, internal stakeholders, and external stakeholders. f) Cutover Management. The Offeror shall describe their methodology transitioning into the production environment hosted by the Shared Service Provider (SSP) including facilities, hardware, software, data, and support transition from the legacy financial system to the new financial system. The management approach shall include processes and procedures for ensuring a seamless transition of the project management responsibilities for cut over from the implementation to the Operations & Maintenance (O&M) phases of the project. g) Staffing Plan and Organizational Structure. Volume II shall also describe the Offeror's staffing plan. The Staffing Plan shall include, at a minimum, the following information: 1. The Offeror shall describe its proposed project organization structure, including the roles and responsibilities of each company or organization that is a member of the team; 2. A description of each role on the project team and the responsibilities of that role; 3. An organizational chart that defines the relationships between the roles, identifies the assigned personnel for each role, and indicates which individuals are key personnel. Where personnel have not been named, indicate the role and the number of proposed personnel; 4. The Offeror shall describe a process for ensuring sufficient experienced personnel are assigned who are qualified in the conduct of similar operations (including but not limited to federal financial system implementation expertise, project management, risk management, earned value management, technical and functional expertise, organizational change management and
Page 44

communications, training expertise, data conversion expertise, application management expertise, and IT administration expertise) and who have relevant backgrounds and experience; 5. A description of how the Offeror will incentivize retention of staff that are identified as key personnel; 6. A staff continuity methodology that addresses the method of ensuring project continuity during staff transition throughout the life of the contract; 7. The Offeror shall identify key personnel consistent with the key personnel requirements identified in the PWS. Key personnel include only those persons who will be assigned to this project and who will be the actual personnel responsible for management and/or performance in the event the proposal results in award. The Offeror may propose one individual for multiple key personnel positions. In such event, the Offeror shall include the rationale for this staffing methodology in the Staffing Plan. The Staffing Plan shall identify those key personnel that hold project management certifications, such as the Project Management Institute's Project Management Professional (PMP) certification. i. The Offeror shall provide the resumes of all key personnel. Resumes shall be no more than two (2) pages long. Resumes shall include the individual's specific experiences that are directly related to the objectives and requirements of this RFP and clearly demonstrate the relationship between each proposed individual's relevant professional certifications and qualifications, and the tasks or role to be performed by that individual. Past experience shall be listed in reverse chronological order, with the latest dates of employment first, and will identify the company or agency, period of employment, title and job description of the individual, and level of responsibility; ii. All proposed key personnel require written, signed (by employee/contingency hire), and dated letters of commitment. The Offeror shall provide letters of commitment from current employees; iii. Letters of commitment must be submitted for contingency hires, defined as persons not currently employed but who have executed a binding letter of commitment for employment with the Offeror, if the Offeror receives award under subject solicitation. The letter of commitment must reflect agreement on salary, benefits and position. New hires may not be proposed for key personnel. (A new hire is defined as specified or unspecified persons to fill an empty position who are neither identified as a current employee of the Offeror (or proposed subcontractor) nor as a contingency hire); 8. In the event teaming or subcontracting arrangements are proposed for accomplishing the required work, the Offeror shall describe how the prospective team subcontractors were chosen as part of the Offeror's proposed team and rationale for selection. The Offeror shall describe the prime contractor's management structure and internal controls to ensure efficient and quality performance of team subcontractors. Factor 3: Past Performance (Volume III) Volume III shall consist of three Past Performance references that are applicable for the IDIQ contract and Task Order 1. To help Offerors determine relevant contracts to include in this volume, NSF provides the following Past Performance Relevance Profile for suggested Past Performance descriptions: Past Performance References shall include the following:
Page 45

a) The system installed is a fully operational Federal financial system compliant with Core Financial system; b) The client had 150 or more total financial system users; c) The work performed included a system life cycle implementation activity, such as those included in this solicitation (e.g., requirements definition, system design, testing, data conversion, and training), hosting services, operations and maintenance, enhancement services, and business transactional services); d) The Past Performance section shall include three (3) current contracts or contracts completed within the last three (3) years that are relevant to the RFP and requirements listed in the PWS. ; and e) The Offeror's historic performance as a hosting provider, including discussion of the system availability for previous and current hosting and IT Administration customers. The Offeror shall provide a detailed overview and scope of work that was performed for each past performance reference that are discussed and the results achieved. Each overview shall not exceed two (2) pages. To facilitate NSF's understanding of past performance information , the Offeror shall discuss its past performance solutions in terms of the original software name (i.e., the name that the software vendor assigned to the software) and not names assigned to the solution by the client or the Offeror. Offerors may provide information on problems encountered and corrective actions taken, on any of the contracts identified in Volume III. Offeror's shall send a copy of the Past Performance Questionnaire (Attachment H) to each customer references for each of the contracts or subcontracts discussed in this section and provide clear instructions for completed questionnaires to be submitted to the Government by the date set forth for proposal submission. It is the responsibility of the Offeror to ensure that questionnaire information is submitted to the Government by the proposal due date. Each customer shall submit the completed questionnaire to Thurl Frazier, Contracting Officer, 4201 Wilson Boulevard Suite 475, Arlington, VA 22230. Questionnaires may also be emailed to tfrazier@nsf.gov.

Factor 4 Price (Volume IV (IDIQ) and Volume VI (Task Order 1)) Volume IV and volume VI shall consist of the following: the Offeror's Cover Letter and the Offeror's price proposal information. Please note that private sector Offerors must cite their Tax Identification Number (TIN), Dun & Bradstreet Number (DUNS), North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS), and other pertinent information. The price proposals shall be submitted for each Contract Line Item Number (CLIN) in the specified format (Time and Materials, Firm Fixed Price) for the base period and each option period as set forth in Attachment I of this solicitation. Pricing information must include fully burdened labor rates for all time and materials labor categories propose and firm fixed pricing for fixed price task orders that our inclusive all costs associated with performing such task orders. Offerors are also required to provide G&A rates for each year of the contract,
including options that would be applied to Other Direct Costs for and Materials task orders authorized by the Government under the contract. Offerors are not to propose Other Direct Costs associated with Time and Materials Task Orders. (Government estimated values of Other Direct Costs will be used for evaluation purposes.) All Offerors

shall provide separate pricing for the descriptions that are identified in the table below:

Factor 5 Extent of Participation of Small Disadvantaged Business Concerns (Volume V) (Notice: Only Applicable to Large Business Concerns submitting Proposals under this RFP.) SUBCONTRACTING APPROACH

This Factor is

The Offeror shall provide an approach to subcontracting that addresses the degree of participation of, subcontracting opportunities for, and the extent the Offeror plans to identify and commit to subcontracting with small business, small disadvantaged business, and veteran-owned, service-disabled, HUBZone, and woman-owned small businesses. The offeror's approach shall include proposed subcontracting goals and plans for successful accomplishment of the goals. SUBCONTRACTING PLAN The Offeror shall submit a Small Business and Small Disadvantaged Business Subcontracting Plan, in accordance with FAR Subpart 19.7 and FAR 52.219-9. Failure to submit such a plan will render the Offeror ineligible for award. The goals, stated below, should be used as guidance for developing a subcontracting plan in response to this RFP. In addition, Offerors shall also provide annual and semi-annual reports from the Electronic Subcontracting Reporting System (eSRS) at www.esrs.gov to demonstrate a record of previous performance in carrying out the goals of subcontracting plans. If the Offeror has had no previous contracts requiring a subcontracting plan, include a statement to that effect in the proposal. The goals listed below represent the subcontract dollar percentage of total contact dollars for work performed within the U.S. Provide details, percentages, performance incentives, and evidence of corporate commitment for each small business category addressed. In addition, Offerors shall provide the anticipated dollar amount for each of the small business categories. Total Small Business Small Disadvantaged Business Women-Owned Small Business HUBZone Business Service-Disabled Veteran-Owned Small Business 17.65% 5.0% 5.0% 3.0% 3.0%

E.9 FAR 52.212-2 Evaluation--Commercial Items (JAN 1999) (a) The Government will award a contract or Interagency Agreement resulting from this solicitation to the responsible offeror whose offer conforms to the solicitation and will be most advantageous to the Government, price and other factors considered. NSF will evaluate proposals for the IDIQ contract and Task Order 1 requirements based upon four (4) factors in descending order of importance: 1. Technical; 2. Management Approach; 3. Past Performance; 4. Price and 5. Extent of Participation of Small Disadvantaged Business Concerns.
Page 48

Factor 1: Technical The technical evaluation factor will receive an overall adjectival rating. NSF will evaluate the following technical subfactors for the IDIQ contract and Task Order 1 requirements which are of equal importance: Subfactor A: Technical Approach The Government will evaluate the thoroughness, soundness, and comprehensiveness of the Offeror's understanding of technical requirements for achieving NSF objectives. Subfactor B: Implementation Services The Government will evaluate the thoroughness, soundness, and comprehensiveness of the Offeror's understanding of implementation requirements for achieving NSF objectives. Subfactor C: Integration with NSF Systems The Government will evaluate the thoroughness, soundness, and comprehensiveness of the Offeror's understanding of integration with NSF systems requirements for achieving NSF objectives. Subfactor D: Integration with Federal Systems The Government will evaluate the thoroughness, soundness, and comprehensiveness of the Offeror's understanding of integration with Federal systems requirements for achieving NSF objectives. Subfactor E: Hosting Services During Implementation The Government will evaluate the thoroughness, soundness, and comprehensiveness of the Offeror's understanding of the hosting during implementation requirements for achieving NSF objectives. Subfactor F: Organizational Change Management and Training The Government will evaluate the thoroughness, soundness, and comprehensiveness of the Offeror's understanding of organizational and change management requirements for achieving NSF objectives. Subfactor G: Hosting (Post Implementation) The Government will evaluate the thoroughness, soundness, and comprehensiveness of the Offeror's understanding of hosting requirements for achieving NSF objectives. Subfactor H: Operations and Maintenance Services The Government will evaluate the thoroughness, soundness, and comprehensiveness of the Offeror's understanding of operations and maintenance requirements for achieving NSF objectives. Subfactor I: Transition Services The Government will evaluate the thoroughness, soundness, and comprehensiveness of the Offeror's understanding of transition requirements for achieving NSF objectives. Subfactor J: Enhancement Services The Government will evaluate the thoroughness, soundness, and comprehensiveness of the Offeror's understanding of enhancement requirements for achieving NSF objectives.
Page 49

Subfactor K: Business Process Support Services The Government will evaluate the thoroughness, soundness, and comprehensiveness of the Offeror's understanding of business process support requirements for achieving NSF objectives. Factor 2 Management Approach The Management Approach factor will receive an overall adjectival rating. NSF will evaluate the Management Approach for the IDIQ contract and Task Order 1 requirements for comprehensiveness, soundness, and the probability of successfully achieving NSF objectives. Factor 3 Past Performance Past Performance will receive an overall adjectival rating for the IDIQ contract and Task Order 1 requirements and will be evaluated for relevance to NSF's requirement, the quality of performance within the last three (3) years, and the amount of responsibility the Offeror had in performance. In conducting the Past Performance evaluation, the Government may use data provided by the Offeror in its proposal as well as data obtained from other sources. NSF will collect and evaluation Past Performance Questionnaires and past performance information provided by the contributor. Factor 4 Price The Government will evaluate the sum of the total estimated cost and total price of the base years and each option year. The price for the IDIQ contract and Task Order 1 will be evaluated by the Government for reasonableness and appropriateness for the proposed mix of labor categories and hours for achieving NSF objectives.

(b) Options. The Government will evaluate offers for award purposes by adding the total price for all options to the total price for the basic requirement. The Government may determine that an offer is unacceptable if the option prices are significantly unbalanced. Evaluation of options shall not obligate the Government to exercise the option(s). (c) A written notice of award or acceptance of an offer mailed or otherwise furnished to the successful offeror within the time for acceptance specified in the offer, shall result in a binding contract without further action by either party. Before the offer's specified expiration time, the Government may accept an offer (or part of an offer), whether or not there are negotiations after its receipt, unless a written notice of withdrawal is received before award. Factor 5 Extent of Participation of Small Disadvantage Business Concerns The Government will assess the Offeror's proposed subcontracting goals and approach to subcontracting will be evaluated based on the degree of participation, providing subcontracting opportunities for, and the extent the Offeror plans to identify and commit to subcontracting with small business, small disadvantaged business, and veteran-owned, service-disabled, HUBZone, and woman-owned small businesses. The Offeror's proposal will be evaluated to determine the realism of the proposed subcontracting goals and the likelihood of successful accomplishment of the goals.

Page 50

The Extent of Participation of Small Disadvantaged Business Concerns Factor shall be evaluated using the "meets/fails to meet" criteria. E.10 SOURCE SELECTION The source selection decision will be based on a Best Value tradeoff determination. Contractors are required to submit all technical and business proposals to the NSF Division of Acquisition and Cooperative Support (DACS) by the specified time and date as indicated in the RFP to be considered for an award. NSF intends to evaluate proposals and make an award without discussions with offerors (except clarifications as described in FAR 15.306(a)). Therefore, the offeror's initial proposal should contain the offeror's best terms from a cost/price and technical standpoint. The Government reserves the right to conduct discussions if the Contracting Officer later determines them to be necessary. If the Contracting Officer determines that the number of proposals that would otherwise be in the competitive range exceeds the number at which an efficient competition can be conducted, the Contracting Officer may limit the number of proposals in the competitive range to the greatest number that will permit an efficient competition among the most highly rated proposals. NSF will make an award to the responsible contractor or Federal entity whose offer conforms to the RFP, has no deficiencies, and is most advantageous to the Government, with price and other factors considered. For this procurement, proposed pricing will be considered in an award determination. However, factors such as Technical, Management Approach, and Past Performance when considered together are significantly more important than cost or price. The Contracting Officer will determine whether the difference in technical quality and past performance is worth the difference price. E.11 NSF 140 NSF ACQUISITION OMBUDSMAN (OCT 2011) (a) An NSF Acquisition Ombudsman has been appointed to hear and facilitate the resolution of concerns from offerors, potential offerors, and others for this acquisition. The existence of the ombudsman does not affect the authority of the contracting officer, selection official, or contracting officer's technical representative. Further, the ombudsman does not participate in the evaluation of proposals, the source selection process, or the adjudication of protests or formal contract disputes. The ombudsman may refer the party to another official who can resolve the concern. (b) Before consulting with the NSF Acquisition Ombudsman, interested parties must first address their concerns, issues, disagreements, and/or recommendations to the contracting officer for resolution. Consulting an ombudsman does not alter or postpone the timelines for any other processes (e.g., agency level bid protests, GAO bid protests, requests for debriefings, employee-employer actions). (c) If resolution cannot be made by the contracting officer, concerned parties may contact the NSF Acquisition Ombudsman. The contact information for the NSF Acquisition Ombudsman may be found at http://www.nsf.gov/bfa/DACS/ombud.jsp. (d) The NSF Acquisition Ombudsman has no authority to render a decision that binds the agency. (e) Do not contact the NSF Acquisition Ombudsman to request copies of the solicitation, verify offer due date, or clarify technical requirements. Such inquiries shall be directed to the Contracting Officer.

Page 51

(f) The Office of the National Ombudsman of the U.S. Small Business Administration has asked all Federal agencies to make clear that, if a small business entity requests Ombudsman assistance on a matter or otherwise questions or complains about a Federal agency action, the agency will not retaliate in response. The National Science Foundation is committed to maintaining an environment in which small businesses and others are free to question or complain about NSF actions or policies without fear of retaliation. One of the statutory responsibilities of the NSF, through its Office of Small Business Research and Development, is to "assure the expeditious processing of proposals by small business concerns based on scientific and technical merit" [42 U.S.C. 1883(3)]. Any allegations of retaliation will be investigated and appropriate action taken to correct the situation and ensure it is not repeated. In addition, small business entities may comment to the National Ombudsman's office. Information about the National Ombudsman is available by visiting www.sba.gov/ombudsman.

Page 52

NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION

TASK ORDER 1: Financial System Implementation and Integration Services

Table of Contents

2

1.0 Task Order 1 Implementation and Integration Services
Task Order 1 is to provide services to support the National Science Foundation (NSF) in implementing a commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) Core Financial management system and key interfaces in a hosted environment within an 18-month implementation schedule. NSF seeks to establish a hybrid of a Time and Materials and Firm Fixed Priced Task Order for providing implementation and integration services.

2.0 Required Products & Services
The items listed below shall be supplied and performed in accordance with this Task Order and with the terms and conditions of the contract. The Contractor must furnish the following: 1. Implementation services 2. Integration services 3. Hosting services during integration and deployment 4. Project Management 5. Organizational Change Management & Training 6. Software Licenses The iTRAK project timeline calls for the implementation effort to begin April 1, 2012 and for the new financial system to achieve full operational capability in a hosted environment by October 1, 2013. NSF prefers to go-live at the beginning of the fiscal year. Full operational capability is defined as the iTRAK Core Financial system becoming NSF's financial system of record, with all FSIO and NSF requirements; batch and on-line financial transactions executed at the hosted location, all NSF interfaces fully functional and all reports should be configured, working and accessible by users on October 1, 2013. NSF does not intend to customize the COTS financial management solution and instead will adopt business processes to realize the full benefits of the best practices and efficiencies built into the COTS software. NSF unique requirements will be addressed with configuration and not customization. Specific requirements are detailed in Attachment B: iTRAK Business Requirements, Attachment C: Interface Requirements, and Attachment E: Service Level Agreement Technical Requirements.

2.1 Implementation Services
The Contractor's proposed implementation approach and schedule shall demonstrate the interdependencies of all activities. The Contractor shall provide all necessary services for the successful implementation of a COTS Core Financial management system that is compliant with Federal Financial System requirements and meets all guidelines identified in OMB Memo 10-26, OMB Circulars A-11, A-123, A-127, A-130, and A-134. The following implementation services objectives have been identified: System Configuration - The Contractor shall configure the system software incorporating the requirements provided in Attachment B: iTRAK Business Requirements, Attachment C: Interface Requirements. The Contractor's solution shall meet all Federal Financial System requirements, NSF specific requirements, and OMB Memo 10-26. The Contractor shall conduct a requirements fit/gap analysis to identify gaps between
3

software functionality and NSF requirements. Conduct Conference Room Pilot(s) to demonstrate that the end-to-end business processes are functioning as required. Data Migration and Conversion ­ The Contractor shall perform activities required to successfully convert and migrate data from its current locations and formats to a new physical location(s) and format(s) defined by the iTRAK solution prior to deployment. These activities shall include at a minimum developing and executing a plan for data migration, conversion, and cutover from the legacy system. NSF plans to convert open documents, open balances, and supporting master data. Testing ­ The Contractor shall perform incremental testing for the new system including unit tests for all components to ensure proper functionality as well as provide testing activities using NSF financial data prior to going live. Testing activities shall include but are not limited to: o Unit Testing o Integration/End-to-End Testing o System Performance Testing (Load Testing) o Data Conversion and Migration Testing o Regression Testing o User Acceptance Testing (UAT) o Backup and Restore Testing o Disaster Recovery Testing The system tests shall encompass a year's worth of financial transactions. The Contractor shall conduct the system tests with testing tools that can simulate data entry and posting of the defined set of transactions to allow full testing of iTRAK, including annual closing and bringing forward the General Ledger beginning balances prior to going live. The Contractor shall ensure the system tests shall include the following components: online entry of transactions; online, real-time interfaces; batch loading of interfaces; production of standard reports; annual closing; and bringing forward the General Ledger beginning balances. The Contractor shall compare the results from the system tests to both expected results and to actual results in the legacy financial system. The Contractor shall be expected to conduct specific testing and establish processes prior to the go live date. Accounting Code Structure - The Contractor shall assist NSF in developing a new accounting code structure and chart of accounts that is compliant with federal guidance for financial management including Treasury and OMB mandates. The Contractor shall assist in mapping the new chart of accounts to the legacy chart of accounts. Financial Reports ­ The Contractor shall provide all financial reports as specified in the reporting requirements in Attachment B: iTRAK Business Requirements. System Deployment / Release Management ­ The Contractor shall perform deployment activities and migration support.

4

NSF System Interface Development - The Contractor shall develop interfaces, test, and support interfaces to internal NSF systems. The Contractor shall develop functional and technical design specification documents for interfaces. NSF is in the process of changing the FAS interfaces to operate on "Open Standards" such as Web Services and Data Services. This transition is planned to be completed in time for the iTRAK implementation. NSF system interfaces are provided in the tables below.
Key Interfaces NSF-Specific Interfaces Awards Description Initiates obligations, de-obligations, Continuing Grant Increment (CGI) mass commitments, and de-commitment of CGIs in the financial system. 2.4 Hosting Services during implementation and integration
The Contractor shall provide hosting services during integration and deployment to support solution development, configuration, integration, data migration, testing, and staging. The hosting solution shall be in compliance with OMB guidelines and includes all services necessary to deliver the proposed approach from project initiation through system cut-over. The following hosting services objectives have been identified: Hardware and software - The Contractor shall provide hardware, software, and services for development; environments for configuration, integration, staging, data migration and conversion, all testing and training. All hardware and software shall be hosted in the Contractor's facility.

9

Security Management - The Contractor shall establish and maintain application security and access controls for all development, test, and conversion environments. Perform password resets; maintain access request files. Hosting services during implementation deliverables include but are not limited to those listed in the table below.

2.5 Project Management
The Contractor shall provide comprehensive and effective life cycle project management services and shall employ a management approach that is consistent with NSF's system development methodology, the Continuous Improvement Program (CIP) and project management best practices, notably those specified by the Project Management Institute (PMI). Details on CIP can be found in Attachment D: Division of Information Systems (DIS) Systems Development Lifecycle. The Contractor shall provide detailed information on the project management structure, resources and support methodology. The Contractor's project management support services, tools and processes shall include, but are not limited to: Schedule Management ­ The development, management, and control of project schedules. Scope Management - The managmenet and control of the work that needs to be accomplished to deliver the financial management solution. Risk Management ­ The planning, identification, analysis, responses, monitoring and control of project risks. Project Financial Management - Management of implementation project budget, control of costs, and monitoring Earned Value metrics using NSF's Earned Value Management System. See contract EVM clause. Document Management ­ The timely and appropriate generation, collection, distribution, storage, retrieval and disposition of project information.

10

Requirements Management ­ Management, traceability and documentation of system requirements. Software Change Management ­ The standardization of methods and procedures for efficient and prompt handling of all software and hardware changes, changes to the project schedule, scope and budget; and support of the iTRAK Change Control Board (CCB). Configuration Management ­ Configuration management activities, change request support, baseline creation, and governance. Quality Control ­ The support of business outcomes, operational metrics, and quality management. Cutover Management ­ The activities associated with transitioning into the production environment hosted by the Shared Service Provider (SSP) including facilities, hardware, software, data, and support transition from the legacy financial system to the new financial system. CIP Documentation Support - Support reviews required by the NSF's system development methodology, the Continuous Improvement Program (CIP) by providing data and information to complete the required artifiact for each CIP phase identified in Attachment D: Division of Information Systems (DIS) Systems Development Lifecycle. Provide gate review support, briefings, and presentations for key stakeholder meetings. Weekly Status Meetings - The Contractor shall conduct weekly status meetings at the NSF location with the Contracting Officer's Technical Representative (COTR), NSF Project Management, and Project Management Team. These meetings will include a review of project metrics, project schedule, risks, issues, and recommended mitigation. Ad hoc Meetings - The Contractor shall be available on site at the NSF location within two (2) hours of notification of an ad hoc meeting request. The Contractor shall be available for ad hoc conference calls within thirty (30) minutes of request. Weekly Status Reports - The Contractor shall provide a weekly status report to the NSF Project Management team including: status of all on-going activities, issues and risks and associated mitigation or remediation recommendations, as well as upcoming activities for the next week. Additionally, any major meetings shall be noted, and the Contractor shall provide a weekly update to the master project schedule to the COTR and Project Manager. Monthly Technical Status Reports - The Contractor shall provide a monthly status report to the NSF Project Management team including: status of all on-going activities including percent complete, issues and risks and associated mitigation or remediation recommendations, upcoming activities for the next month, an assessment of technical

11

progress, schedule status, and performance metric data. meetings shall be noted.

Additionally, any major

Monthly Financial Status Reports - - The Contractor shall provide a monthly financial status report. The report should include, at a minimum, the effort performed during that period and should outline the labor hours used (by labor category) and costs incurred (current period and cumulative), funding remaining, and EVM metrics. Project management deliverables include but are not limited to those listed in the table below.

2.6 Organizational Change Management & Training
Organizational change management is a critical function in ensuring the acceptance and adoption of the new iTRAK financial system by NSF stakeholders. NSF requires transformation that aligns the business processes with the COTS solution. The Contractor shall be an active participant in the identification of transformational and organizational change issues (e.g., stakeholder transition, communications, and training) and in developing strategies for mitigating the impact and facilitating the adoption of new and reengineered business processes and supporting services. The Contractor's organizational change services, tools and processes shall include, but are not limited to:  Communications - The Contractor shall identify new and existing NSF communication mediums and forums that clearly communicate the anticipated changes; work collaboratively with the NSF iTRAK Project Management Office (PMO) to manage expectations and inform internal and external stakeholders about the benefits of adopting the system. Organizational change - The Contractor shall develop and execute an organizational change management plan. Identify and assess organizational resistance; develop tailored strategies and plans to help guide specific stakeholder groups through the deployment and post deployment transition; and promote the benefits of the transformed business process. Training - The Contractor shall develop a system training plan, training materials, and deliver the system training to NSF users. The Contractor's approach shall take into consideration the number and type (transactional and reporting) of NSF users. Training delivery shall reflect multiple delivery approaches to include web-based and instructor led classroom training. The training schedule shall be tied to the iTRAK testing and deployment schedule and include pre-deployment and post deployment training. Training shall include performance based and cognitive training methods. The computer training room at NSF headquarters will be made available for iTRAK training activities. The Contractor shall include an onsite learning lab environment to provide users in-person assistance during and post go-live. Below is information showing approximate user types for training purposes. Changes may be required when business processes are aligned to the iTRAK system. User Type Description Estimated Number of Users 44

Transactional - Heavy

Daily users, analytical reports, data queries, invoices, approving and paying, entering receivables, ad hoc data integration capabilities.

13

Transactional Moderate Transactional - Light

Weekly users, analytical reports, data queries, invoices, 176 approving and paying, entering receivables, ad hoc data integration capabilities. Periodic data entry of requisitions, approvals, report running and receiving activities. Estimated Total Number of Users 341 561

4.

Full operational capability in a hosted environment by October 1, 2013. Full operational capability is defined as the iTRAK Core Financial system becoming NSF's financial system of record, with all financial transactions, batch or on-line, being done at the hosted location and all interfaces functioning. 4.0 System Acceptance
The system shall be accepted with no severity 1 & 2 issues. Negligible Severity 3 issues (below 2% of total system transactions) and severity 4 &5 (below 5%). Explanation on each severity level: Severity 1 - Catastrophic defect that causes total failure of the software or unrecoverable data loss. There is no work around. In general, a severity 1 defect would prevent the product from being released. Example: defects that cause the system to crash, corrupt data files, or completely disrupt service. Severity 2 - Defect results in severely impaired functionality. A work around may exist but its use is unsatisfactory. In general, you would not release the product with such a defect. Examples: with certain steps, we may generate a Windows error/message that you can click Ok on and continue with whatever you were doing with no harmful effects. Severity 3 - Defect causes failure of non-critical aspects of the system. There is a reasonably satisfactory work around. The product may be released if the defect is documented, but the existence of the defect may cause customer dissatisfaction. Example: a non Client Financial Report is not recognizing an option correctly, but if a filter is set, the report can be generated with the proper output. Severity 4 - Defect of minor significance. A work around exists or, if not, the impairment is slight. Generally, the product could be released and most customers would be unaware of the defect's existence or only slightly dissatisfied. Example: A button or button set is slightly off center on a data screen, or the problem is purely cosmetic and not easily recognizable. Severity 5 - Enhancement request or design issue. These should probably be coded as Suggestions or brought to the Design Team by the originating person's DT representative.
